revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-10 14:01:04.000000000', 'message': "Fix iteration over remote_ip_prefixes field

The remote_ip_prefixes filed of a KuryrNetPolicy has the
format: {'remote_ip_prefixes': {'pod_ip': 'np-namespace'}}.
Right now, we're iterating over each remote_ip_prefixes
dicts and retrieving its keys and values without fetching the
dict items causing a ValueError. This commit fixes the
issue by iterating over the dict items.

Closes-bug: 1858301

Change-Id: Ic40878a830bcc32da06c0ab2763f593595e81bf2
(cherry picked from commit 674344b1826b4e2724b3fc397f20984fe6a8ad9c)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix iteration over remote_ip_prefixes field

The remote_ip_prefixes filed of a KuryrNetPolicy has the
format: {'remote_ip_prefixes': {'pod_ip': 'np-namespace'}}.
Right now, we're iterating over each remote_ip_prefixes
dicts and retrieving its keys and values without fetching the
dict items causing a ValueError. This commit fixes the
issue by iterating over the dict items.

Closes-bug: 1858301

Change-Id: Ic40878a830bcc32da06c0ab2763f593595e81bf2
(cherry picked from commit 674344b1826b4e2724b3fc397f20984fe6a8ad9c)

commit_message:
WIP: Change concurrency implementation on buildah

This new implementation should give better feedback regarding execution
errors regardless if they happen due to python exceptions or timeouts.

Previous implementation was randomly failing because it was checking a
a list of unfinished futures. The result was usually a failure without
any failures listed inside.

Change-Id: I5f725df9ff4c39dab85d90e62fbd16de85d51c82

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-08 00:29:54.000000000', 'message': 'Improve ChefSpec test speed by enabling caching

This updates all references of let(:chef_run) to cached(:chef_run) to
speed up tests. By doing this, we have to create a new cached(:chef_run)
block whenever we need to adjust node attributes for testing.

Speed was improved from 56 minutes 34 seconds to 8 minutes 43 seconds

Change-Id: Ic7cf02200cf9d09beb66f6aa0d27cadffa65f7c9
'}]
commit_message:
Improve ChefSpec test speed by enabling caching

This updates all references of let(:chef_run) to cached(:chef_run) to
speed up tests. By doing this, we have to create a new cached(:chef_run)
block whenever we need to adjust node attributes for testing.

Speed was improved from 56 minutes 34 seconds to 8 minutes 43 seconds

Change-Id: Ic7cf02200cf9d09beb66f6aa0d27cadffa65f7c9

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-09 08:31:58.000000000', 'message': 'Revert InstancePCIRequest change when live migration aborted

During live migration the conductor updates the InstancePCIRequest for
qos SRIOV ports according to the selected destination host. When such
live migration is aborted we need to roll back the change to keep the
data in InstancePCIRequest sync with the reality that the instance is
rolled back to the source host.

This data inconsistency does not cause any end user visible side effect
as such InstancePCIRequest will be updated again during the next move
operation of the instance. But it is ugly that we have invalid data in
the db and in the future some operation might want to depend on the fact
that the data is in sync.

There is one complication. If the migration is already running then
the _do_live_migration or the virt driver will call
_rollback_live_migration with a potentially stale Instance object as it
was read when the migration is started. As _rollback_live_migration will
save such Instance object to the db we have to make sure that it does
not overwrite what the live_migration_abort did in the db. So this patch
adds an instance.refresh() call to the start of the
_rollback_live_migration function.

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

Change-Id: I7b37f84257e1f4a07929cf1b282f013ff7bd68e8

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

Change-Id: I7b37f84257e1f4a07929cf1b282f013ff7bd68e8

commit_message:
Revert InstancePCIRequest change when live migration aborted

During live migration the conductor updates the InstancePCIRequest for
qos SRIOV ports according to the selected destination host. When such
live migration is aborted we need to roll back the change to keep the
data in InstancePCIRequest sync with the reality that the instance is
rolled back to the source host.

This data inconsistency does not cause any end user visible side effect
as such InstancePCIRequest will be updated again during the next move
operation of the instance. But it is ugly that we have invalid data in
the db and in the future some operation might want to depend on the fact
that the data is in sync.

There is one complication. If the migration is already running then
the _do_live_migration or the virt driver will call
_rollback_live_migration with a potentially stale Instance object as it
was read when the migration is started. As _rollback_live_migration will
save such Instance object to the db we have to make sure that it does
not overwrite what the live_migration_abort did in the db. So this patch
adds an instance.refresh() call to the start of the
_rollback_live_migration function.

blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

Change-Id: I7b37f84257e1f4a07929cf1b282f013ff7bd68e8

Fix lower constraints for tests work again.

* neutron, networking-bagpipe, networking-sfc and networking-odl
  are removed from lower-constraints.txt. They are installed
  from a same branch and are released per cycle, so including them
  in lower-constraints does not make sense until a beta release is
  cut during a development cycle.
* horizon requirement is updated to match the Ussuri deliverable.
  horizon switched the release model to cycle-with-intermediary in Ussuri
  so we can specify horizon version in lower-constraints.txt.

Updated entries are identified and verified in the following steps:

* Check ERROR line in .tox/lower-constraints/log/lower-constraints-1.log
* Check all modules are installed baesd on lower-constraints-1.log
  and no '>=x.y.z' requirements appears.
* After creating 'lower-constraints' tox venv, neutron,
  networking-bagpipe, networking-sfc and networking-odl are installed
  manually using .tox/lower-constraints/bin/pip and check no additional
  modules are installed. If some modules are installed, it means they
  should be covered by lower-constraints.txt.

Signed-off-by: Thomas Morin <thomas.morin@orange.com>
Submitted on behalf of a third-party: Orange

commit_message:
Fix lower constraints

Fix lower constraints for tests work again.

* neutron, networking-bagpipe, networking-sfc and networking-odl
  are removed from lower-constraints.txt. They are installed
  from a same branch and are released per cycle, so including them
  in lower-constraints does not make sense until a beta release is
  cut during a development cycle.
* horizon requirement is updated to match the Ussuri deliverable.
  horizon switched the release model to cycle-with-intermediary in Ussuri
  so we can specify horizon version in lower-constraints.txt.

Updated entries are identified and verified in the following steps:

* Check ERROR line in .tox/lower-constraints/log/lower-constraints-1.log
* Check all modules are installed baesd on lower-constraints-1.log
  and no '>=x.y.z' requirements appears.
* After creating 'lower-constraints' tox venv, neutron,
  networking-bagpipe, networking-sfc and networking-odl are installed
  manually using .tox/lower-constraints/bin/pip and check no additional
  modules are installed. If some modules are installed, it means they
  should be covered by lower-constraints.txt.

Signed-off-by: Thomas Morin <thomas.morin@orange.com>
Submitted on behalf of a third-party: Orange

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ie079c93cb752b6aef9b0505a0492719993729621

commit_message:
Get DNS domain for nova metadata

Get the DNS domain for the dhcp_domain setting for nova metadata over
the cloud-compute relation from nova-cloud-controller.

Fixes Bug #1805645 when using provider networks with no network node.

Change-Id: Iaba14e6939ab5d488c6299ce5cb33e26f757cf95
Partial-Bug: #1805645

commit_message:
Cap hacking version to <2

Hacking received a major update to version 2.0.0 that added new checks
that fail on stable branches. Instead of addressing those new check
errors on stable branches, it is better to cap hacking to <2. This way
we'll not see lint errors again should new checks be added in the
future.

Support for hacking 2.0.0 in master branch is being worked in
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699302/

Change-Id: I4706972095d42815a3f3cec0bc5aa82a34922bf3
(cherry picked from commit 85f7abbbaf958458ee12415b0de0e938c20fb121)
(cherry picked from commit d0ef7a823150ea84e0fbb8d54711dfbe8fb9e477)
(cherry picked from commit 1768b17c03437fcb4d1c823987bf71b64139bec5)

> > I wonder if we don't need a releasenote for our users
 > 
 > If they do not use own sources.list then it does not matter as it
 > will still work for them. And usually better than before.
 > 
 > If they use own sources.list then it does not apply to them.

not necessarily - if they use firewalls/proxies or whatever, the will be affected by this change, not that I think they are doing it right atm"}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2020-01-13 08:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-13 08:46:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-13 08:46:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

thanks, Marcin'}, {'account_id': 30523, 'date': '2020-01-13 09:08:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2020-01-13 09:28:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2020-01-14 07:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 30523, 'date': '2020-01-14 07:36:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-14 08:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Ubuntu: use local APT mirrors if possible

APT has a way to fetch mirror list and autoselect best mirror.

Change-Id: I8209770ca1353fd89aacef0859ca3a373645c6b2

commit_message:
Make use of horizon_git_track_branch

This patch aims to make use of horizon_git_track_branch
instead of hardcoding branches to repos we eventually use
for service dashboards.

Change-Id: I1625cd0140c04ac7bfc45575dffeda22358b4fc7

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-09 07:29:34.000000000', 'message': 'Skip horizon-integration-tests for translation jobs

There is no need to run horizon-integration-tests as we use
the default language, English, in the integration tests and
proposed translation files are validated in the pep8 job.
It reduced the CI resources and waiting time.

Change-Id: I70851622a91280eab99005bf285d8190bfbf8933
'}]
commit_message:
Skip horizon-integration-tests for translation jobs

There is no need to run horizon-integration-tests as we use
the default language, English, in the integration tests and
proposed translation files are validated in the pep8 job.
It reduced the CI resources and waiting time.

Change-Id: I70851622a91280eab99005bf285d8190bfbf8933

We pick a command to resize the undercloud image based on its
FS type. Do the same for the overcloud image resizing

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-14 01:05:21.000000000', 'message': 'horizon: put plugins toggles in quotes

Without quotes, it seems like Ansible "from_yaml" filter will convert
yes to True and no to False; which is problematic in the case of Kolla
image for Horizon where the extend_start script checks for yes/no and
not the actual booleans.

Putting them between quotes seems to solve the issue.

Change-Id: Ie08726c0916c55c3d4c315b63ee341196cc2e70e
Closes-Bug: #1859491
(cherry picked from commit 2da9cc14bf05af369c2036c2824d3e701c807467)
'}]
commit_message:
horizon: put plugins toggles in quotes

Without quotes, it seems like Ansible "from_yaml" filter will convert
yes to True and no to False; which is problematic in the case of Kolla
image for Horizon where the extend_start script checks for yes/no and
not the actual booleans.

Putting them between quotes seems to solve the issue.

Change-Id: Ie08726c0916c55c3d4c315b63ee341196cc2e70e
Closes-Bug: #1859491
(cherry picked from commit 2da9cc14bf05af369c2036c2824d3e701c807467)

[{'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:10:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:21:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:33:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:43:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:46:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I'm confused, isn't it already covered by https://github.com/openstack/ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image#yum-update ?"}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 18:48:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The current features don't allow to only update installed packages without using a repository (local or remote). We need to be able to use "yum localupdate" in order to only update existing packages. The current rpm_install.sh that we use to generate hotfixes for customer will work only when all the packages provided through the package are all contained with their dependencies in the container image. Adding "yum localupdate" support kind of solves these issues as we can update only the packages that are already installed.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 19:18:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 19:28:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 19:39:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 19:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 19:58:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:00:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:21:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 7130, 'date': '2020-01-08 20:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15: Patch Set 14 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-01-09 12:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

commit_message:
Add the possibility to update packages from local rpms using yum.

This is needed if we want to only update installed packages and not
hit depenency issues encountered when updating packages with rpm_install.sh

Change-Id: I5095d7b04cb10fde1bd82afd1bc406445b7595fd
Closes-bug: #1858837

commit_message:
Neutron Classifier integration into Neutron QoS

This is the Spec to propose and describe the integration
between the Neutron Quality of Service extension and
the Neutron Classifier service plugin.

Change-Id: I5bfd7dfab8061debd6fb86470c874098cfc48a0b
Implements: blueprint neutron-classifier-neutron-qos

subject: Add support for feature.api
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-13 16:51:33.000000000', 'message': "Add support for feature.api

Despite some of the infrastructure being in place, the 'api' key in an
[operation.*] section was being ignored. This commit adds the code to
look for it so it's reported as expected in the output.

Change-Id: I36bde39742f7f3ee60ee10240d836c7083cfa0fd
"}]
commit_message:
Add support for feature.api

Despite some of the infrastructure being in place, the 'api' key in an
[operation.*] section was being ignored. This commit adds the code to
look for it so it's reported as expected in the output.

Change-Id: I36bde39742f7f3ee60ee10240d836c7083cfa0fd

commit_message:
Replace Fluentd and SensuClient from roles_data.

When using composable roles, we need to make sure that the roles_data file
does not contain the deprecated services Fluentd [0] and SensuClient[1].
This services were replaced in Train by Rsyslog and Collectd respectively.

[0] - I1e12470b4eea86d8b7a971875d28a2a5e50d5e07
[1] - I4be68eb7319b2c92cc7d0fc9df7a5c87dfb5106c

Change-Id: I996cd861a54ad1cc58288058c8a31e7562d93a41

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-30 15:34:53.000000000', 'message': "Add namespaces to Adhoc actions

 when creating an action-definition user can use the option --namespace
 to create the action in that specific namespace, if it was not provided
 the action will be created in the default namespace.
 default namespace is ''.

 *added --namespace to action-definition commands,
 *added --namespace option to run-action

 Depends-On: I07862e30adf28404ec70a473571a9213e53d8a08
 Partially-Implements: blueprint create-and-run-workflows-within-a-namespace

Change-Id: I18dbd9faee06c3cd2209f7e579eeb2e1a24c88d9

commit_message:
Add namespace support for actions to client

 When creating an action-definition user can use the option --namespace
 to create the action in that specific namespace, if it was not provided
 the action will be created in the default namespace.
 default namespace is ''.

 *Added --namespace to action commands,
 *Added --namespace option to run-action

Depends-On: I07862e30adf28404ec70a473571a9213e53d8a08
Implements: blueprint create-and-run-workflows-within-a-namespace

Change-Id: I18dbd9faee06c3cd2209f7e579eeb2e1a24c88d9

commit_message:
Remove deprecated glance-registry from nrpe checks

This patch removes the deprecated glance-registry service from nrpe
checks after an openstack upgrade to an openstack version greater than
Rocky

Closes-Bug: #1849896
Depends-On: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/409

Change-Id: I274441966f15f66341adf30c07c625cc76b2ecb6
Signed-off-by: Alexandros Soumplis <soumplis@admin.grnet.gr>

commit_message:
CentOS 8: Don't force tag in build jobs

We should allow the tag set in kolla-build.conf to be used for the image
tags, since our deploy jobs need to set it to change_XXXXXXX when images
are built for the job.

Change-Id: I705514ee0249ff1d309e280001d653271e3686af
Partially-Implements: blueprint centos-rhel-8

commit_message:
Staging area not cleared if image is deleted while importing

If multiple stores configured in glance and Image is deleted while import
operation is in progress then image data stays in staging area
(filesystem backend) and there is no other way than clearing it
manually.

Modified delete method to delete the data from staging area if image is
deleted while import operation is in progress.
Conflicts:
        glance/api/v2/images.py
        glance/async_/flows/api_image_import.py
        glance/common/store_utils.py

NOTE: Conflicts occured due to reserved store capability is not
available in Stein.

Change-Id: Ib58accd6514e589dccde57fe063815b1ab1ce496
Closes-Bug: #1855417
(cherry picked from commit 5d15f073718328380f2d847e4abfb9307536d810)

commit_message:
Update vpnaas rootwrap filters

The vpnaas rootwrap filters are out of date and therefore not
functional on the latest release of OpenStack Ansible.

This updates and adds all the missing ones so that it becomes
functional again.

Change-Id: Iadcb4c7451cd51526dfd96b305a9d0b1948ce8da

Notes:

- OVN currently doesn't support L7. L7 tempest tests are disabled.
- OVN currently doesn't support health check for LB members. Health monitor

commit_message:
Add OVN Octavia CI jobs

This patch adds Octavia CI jobs for OVN.
Notes:

- OVN currently doesn't support L7. L7 tempest tests are disabled.
- OVN currently doesn't support health check for LB members. Health monitor
  tests are disabled.
- Skipped ipv6 tests because mixing IPv4 and IPv6 members
  is not allowed in OVN.
- OVN currently doesn't support flavors. Related tests are disabled.

Co-Authored-By: Reedip Banerjee <rbanerje@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Carlos Goncalves <cgoncalves@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Maciej Jzefczyk <mjozefcz@redhat.com>

Change-Id: If28ec1ce8179afb47a4ef11ee953f3d7db98408a

[{'created': '2020-01-13 08:45:14.000000000', 'message': 'Use hosts official name for FQDN

The current implementations use of a specific interface to build
FQDN from has the undesired side effect of the ``nova-compute`` and
``neutron-openvswitch`` charms ending up with using different
hostnames in some situations.  It may also lead to use of a
identifier that is mutable throughout the lifetime of a deployment.

Use of a specific interface was chosen due to ``socket.getfqdn()``
not giving reliable results (https://bugs.python.org/issue5004).

This patch gets the FQDN by mimicking the behaviour of a call to
``hostname -f`` with fallback to shortname on failure.

Add relevant update from c-h.

Change-Id: Ic8f8742261b773484687985aa0a366391cd2737a
Closes-Bug: #1839300
(cherry picked from commit ee709a5ab30f285ecc1dd3ddb998af970f22e17e)

commit_message:
Use hosts official name for FQDN

The current implementations use of a specific interface to build
FQDN from has the undesired side effect of the ``nova-compute`` and
``neutron-openvswitch`` charms ending up with using different
hostnames in some situations.  It may also lead to use of a
identifier that is mutable throughout the lifetime of a deployment.

Use of a specific interface was chosen due to ``socket.getfqdn()``
not giving reliable results (https://bugs.python.org/issue5004).

This patch gets the FQDN by mimicking the behaviour of a call to
``hostname -f`` with fallback to shortname on failure.

Add relevant update from c-h.

Change-Id: Ic8f8742261b773484687985aa0a366391cd2737a
Closes-Bug: #1839300
(cherry picked from commit ee709a5ab30f285ecc1dd3ddb998af970f22e17e)

are removed, the removal of the load balancer member is
ignored, as right now the name of the pod is not taken into

current attributes checked are pod ip and port, which remains
the same. This commit fixes the issue by ensuring the
pod name is also checked.

Change-Id: I44f7f76da692ac3002c91a1420969584b4d31cbd

commit_message:
Ensure LB member is removed upon pod removal

When pods that run on host network and are pointed by a svc
are removed, the removal of the load balancer member is
ignored, as right now the name of the pod is not taken into
account on the decision of which members to delete, and the
current attributes checked are pod ip and port, which remains
the same. This commit fixes the issue by ensuring the
pod name is also checked.

Closes-Bug: 1857354
Change-Id: I44f7f76da692ac3002c91a1420969584b4d31cbd
(cherry picked from commit 8c62ce5abf4559272ba8ce7def3decc4b62e8979)

commit_message:
Use hosts official name for FQDN

The current implementations use of a specific interface to build
FQDN from has the undesired side effect of the ``nova-compute`` and
``neutron-openvswitch`` charms ending up with using different
hostnames in some situations.  It may also lead to use of a
identifier that is mutable throughout the lifetime of a deployment.

Use of a specific interface was chosen due to ``socket.getfqdn()``
not giving reliable results (https://bugs.python.org/issue5004).

This patch gets the FQDN by mimicking the behaviour of a call to
``hostname -f`` with fallback to shortname on failure.

Add relevant update from c-h.

Change-Id: I82db81937e5a46dc6bd222b7160ca1fa5b190c10
Closes-Bug: #1839300
(cherry-picked from 1869bfbc9711eac157821f8a4702409822c0842e)

commit_message:
Avoid py36 error when printing unicode chars in a stream

The IOStream was not able to encode characters out of range 128:
  "UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in
   position 19-21: ordinal not in range(128)"

Change-Id: Ic95396a5cf73c49d332928857dc064819a6d7ea6
Closes-Bug: #1858421

commit_message:
Extend post update and upgrade tasks to step 5

There are use cases where a service has to run post update and upgrade
tasks in step 5. For example, Octavia runs workflow tasks (Queens) in
step 5 and needs to be able to run post tasks afterward for cleanup.

Closes-Bug: #1854069
Change-Id: Id0e58a30442a86e3a7a5417c00207693172fdb47

commit_message:
Fixes rally db commands

'rally-manage db' command was deprecated since 0.10.0 [1]. Should use
'rally db' instead.

[1] https://rally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/project_info/release_notes/archive/v0.10.0.html#command-line-interface

Closes-Bug: #1856693

Change-Id: I578f7a6d907d5579180bc64c99c7e6c8edf3afc8
(cherry picked from commit 1114859b5cb940290f405cd64e34c6638dcebcae)

commit_message:
Add support for the query_function field to the Prometheus collector

This extends the possibilities for manipulating data with the Prometheus
collector without using custom scripts.

Work items:
 * Implemented the query_function field in the Prometheus collector.

 * Documented the query_function field.

 * Updated the tests on the Prometheus collector to include the
   query_function field.

Change-Id: If6c2242d876eb40fb9a86a776258d50e7a2a441f
Story: 2006427
Task: 37688

subject: Use neutron rpc for port status checking
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 11600, 'name': 'Micha Dulko', 'email': 'mdulko@redhat.com', 'username': 'dulek'}, {'_account_id': 14352, 'name': 'Antoni Segura Puimedon', 'email': 'celebdor@gmail.com', 'username': 'toni'}, {'_account_id': 14570, 'name': 'Ashish Billore', 'email': 'ash.billore@samsung.com', 'username': 'ashish.billore'}, {'_account_id': 14885, 'name': 'Daniel Mellado', 'email': 'dmellado@redhat.com', 'username': 'daniel-mellado'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23567, 'name': 'Luis Tomas Bolivar', 'email': 'ltomasbo@redhat.com', 'username': 'ltomasbo'}, {'_account_id': 25900, 'name': 'Vladimir Kuramshin', 'email': 'vladimir@kuramsh.in', 'username': 'vkuramshin'}, {'_account_id': 28396, 'name': 'Alexey Perevalov', 'email': 'alexey.perevalov@huawei.com', 'username': 'a.perevalov'}, {'_account_id': 30247, 'name': 'Ilya Maximets', 'email': 'i.maximets@ovn.org', 'username': 'i.maximets'}, {'_account_id': 31502, 'name': 'Andrey Zaikin', 'email': 'zed.0xff@gmail.com', 'username': 'zed_0xff'}]

[{'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-08 11:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-08 11:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Lets discuss here:
1. required dependencies
2. rabbit mq unavailability case
3. move setting active status to daemon'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-08 11:50:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-09 09:00:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-09 13:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-10 12:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-10 16:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-07-11 07:11:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

-1 just to ensure this is not missed. Problem I see with this approach is that kuryr needs to have access to rabbit. That will not be the case for nested envs where kuryr runs completely without any admin needs'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-11 07:18:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> -1 just to ensure this is not missed. Problem I see with this
 > approach is that kuryr needs to have access to rabbit. That will
 > not be the case for nested envs where kuryr runs completely without
 > any admin needs

If rabbit mq is not available, kuryr-controller obtains port status  from neutron as before.'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-07-11 08:01:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> -1 just to ensure this is not missed. Problem I see with this
 > approach is that kuryr needs to have access to rabbit. That will
 > not be the case for nested envs where kuryr runs completely without
 > any admin need

Beside the fact that this patch has a fallback solution with usual neutronclinet, I have a question: Is what you wrote correct for kuryr-k8s controller? I mean that we're using neutron rpc only on controller side and it has access to neutron-server via neutronclient. Doesn't it have access to rabbitmq in this case? They are usually working on the same node."}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-07-18 07:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-07-29 11:04:18.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to bp/neutron-push-notifications'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-07-29 14:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-07-30 08:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> recheck

Looks like kuryr-kubernetes-tempest-multinode-containerized failed due to it was not possible to download deb packages on controller and later it was not possible to connect to OpenStack.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-10-02 09:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Do we still need this with your latest test results?'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-10-02 12:55:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Do we still need this with your latest test results?

This one is needed, due to it's not about kuryr-controller->kuryr-cni interconnection. It's about receiving notification from neutron server through amqp instead just requesting it periodically. Looks like need to rebase it."}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-10-03 13:00:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-10-04 06:44:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-11-08 04:16:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I had a brief talk with Neutron folks about this and they have a few remarks here.

So first of all the patch seems to listen to notifications that are meant for the agents [1]. Apparently there's a second type of notifications, with much more stable API [2]. This may help with compatibility issues.

How Nova (and Ironic) does it is they have a callback that Neutron calls when the port is ready. I think code for that lives in notifiers directory [3]. Apparently it's pretty free-form and we could just add a Kuryr one that would send a PUT request on some K8s API - e.g. update the pod's annotation or KuryrPort CRD (once Roman is finished with it).

Those two ways would resolve all the issues you have with this. I obviously prefer the latter, as making Neutron able to access K8s is easier than making RPC accessible for Kuryr.

Please tell me what you think about this.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/contributor/internals/rpc_callbacks.html#resource-push-notifications
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/admin/archives/adv-operational-features.html#notifications
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/notifiers"}, {'account_id': 28396, 'date': '2019-11-11 15:44:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> I had a brief talk with Neutron folks about this and they have a
 > few remarks here.
 > 
 > So first of all the patch seems to listen to notifications that are
 > meant for the agents [1]. Apparently there's a second type of
 > notifications, with much more stable API [2]. This may help with
 > compatibility issues.
 > 
 > How Nova (and Ironic) does it is they have a callback that Neutron
 > calls when the port is ready. I think code for that lives in
 > notifiers directory [3]. Apparently it's pretty free-form and we
 > could just add a Kuryr one that would send a PUT request on some
 > K8s API - e.g. update the pod's annotation or KuryrPort CRD (once
 > Roman is finished with it).
 > 
 > Those two ways would resolve all the issues you have with this. I
 > obviously prefer the latter, as making Neutron able to access K8s
 > is easier than making RPC accessible for Kuryr.
 > 
 > Please tell me what you think about this.
 > 
 > [1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/contributor/internals/rpc_callbacks.html#resource-push-notifications
 > [2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/pike/admin/archives/adv-operational-features.html#notifications
 > [3] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/notifiers


I had a look at [3]. The concept as I understand -  directly notifying nova from neutron. Also I saw there ironic client. If it feasible for you to reach kuryr-controller from OpenStack controller, I'm ok with this way.

But need to clarify several points:
In [3] neutron sends notification message to os-server-external-events endpoint of nova. So we need to implementes somethings similar to it (or ironic.py there) and send updates to kuryr-kubernetes. Or implement this nova's endpoint on kuryr-kubernetes side. But the latest sounds like a dirty hack.
Frankly saying I didn't find code for [2] yet."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-08 11:37:52.000000000', 'message': 'Use neutron rpc for port status checking

This is the basic implementation of Neutron RPC handler that will
receive all the neutron ports related notifications from the
neutron-server.

For now it's used to replace neutron port status checks by neutron
VIF handler. Instead of requesting port information from the
neutronclient, we're looking at the local port status cache managed
by the neutron RPC handler. This should decrease preassure on
the neutron server.

For this to work 'transport_url' in kuryr.conf should be set to the
same vaule as in neutron.conf. Like this:

    transport_url=rabbit://guest:guest@<ip>:<port>/

This is the new option for the new oslo.messaging dependency.
We also have to have neutron in requirements to use rpc.

With this change we will be able to decrease sleep
time for vif handler if resource is not ready yet, because this will
not lead to any additional requests to Neutron. This ability requires
"Handle neutron errors while activating vif".

Partial-Implements: blueprint neutron-push-notifications

Change-Id: I4434c44e31bb371bb66afdc1026bd1d1a2a1327d
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-07-08 11:50:31.000000000', 'message': "Use neutron rpc for port status checking

For now it's used to replace neutron port status checks by neutron
VIF handler. Instead of requesting port information from the
neutronclient, we're looking at the local port status cache managed
by the neutron RPC handler. This should decrease preassure on
the neutron server.

For this to work 'transport_url' in kuryr.conf should be set to the
same vaule as in neutron.conf. Like this:

    transport_url=rabbit://guest:guest@<ip>:<port>/

This is the new option for the new oslo.messaging dependency.
We also have to have neutron in requirements to use rpc.

With this change we will be able to decrease sleep
time for vif handler if resource is not ready yet, because this will
not lead to any additional requests to Neutron.

Partial-Implements: blueprint neutron-push-notifications

Change-Id: I4434c44e31bb371bb66afdc1026bd1d1a2a1327d
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Use neutron rpc for port status checking

This is the basic implementation of Neutron RPC handler that will
receive all the neutron ports related notifications from the
neutron-server.

For now it's used to replace neutron port status checks by neutron
VIF handler. Instead of requesting port information from the
neutronclient, we're looking at the local port status cache managed
by the neutron RPC handler. This should decrease preassure on
the neutron server.

For this to work 'transport_url' in kuryr.conf should be set to the
same vaule as in neutron.conf. Like this:

    transport_url=rabbit://guest:guest@<ip>:<port>/

This is the new option for the new oslo.messaging dependency.
We also have to have neutron in requirements to use rpc.

With this change we will be able to decrease sleep
time for vif handler if resource is not ready yet, because this will
not lead to any additional requests to Neutron.

Partial-Implements: blueprint neutron-push-notifications

Change-Id: I4434c44e31bb371bb66afdc1026bd1d1a2a1327d
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-10-04 23:58:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9452, 'date': '2019-11-01 18:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

There's a couple ways you would use a tpm, and how you handle the secret is relevant to that. Here's a couple examples

Example 1:

The instance in question is used as a component in a secure root of trust. This instance will communicate with an HSM to sign x509 CSRs, SSHCA certificates, or otherwise encrypt things.

The flow for provisioning that secret would be:
1. User creates an instance

2. User logs in and provisions the TPM, they are now the 'owner' of the vTPM
  1. they "take ownership" of the tpm and supply a new ownership password in the process. (That master password is only used to provision new SRK, SK, etc keys inside of the TPM.)
  2. The owner then provisions a storage key in the tpm (SRK) and supplies a -new secret- for that key.

3. The owner now creates an asymmetric keypair and uses the tpm to seal the private key they just created. The original private key file is then deleted. Now what you have is a blob of the private key which has been encrypted by the TPM.
  a. If the owner chose to seal the key with PCRs in the process, then the TPM will require both the PCR values to be correct as well as the SRK secret before decrypting the keyblob. This is useful because now the TPM data cannot just be moved to another machine and decrypted there. it will only work in this exact environment.

3. The owner now works with whatever other security officers are necessary to access the HSM and place the public key created in the previous step into the HSM as a trusted auth credential

4. With the TPM unlocked the application on the instance can now use the TPM to establish a mTLS connection to the HSM and request that the HSM sign things. 

If the instance reboots, a human must log in and use their secret to unlock the TPM, then make a call to decrypt the keyblob. 

In this example the secrets necessary to unlock the tpm and subsequently decrypt the private keys are known only to humans, and root access to the hypervisor would not give you the credentials necessary to decrypt the vTPM object, as the master password is needed for that.

Example 2:

This is a mutation of example 1. The steps are the same, except that the secret to unlock the TPM is stored in a key managament service. In our environment we use HSMs to provide a unique x509 identity to every instance in our datacenters.

1. When the instance is first created a x509 keypair is automatically provisioned at boot time and stored on the filesystem and signed by a secure root of trust
2. Steps 1-3 are followed as above
3. The SRK is stored in a key management service such as Barbican, KMS, or an in-house solution (hi). Access to that secret is granted to the instances x509 public key
4. Now, on boot the instance will connect to the secure key management service to grab the SRK secret, use that to unlock the tpm, and subsequently decrypt the private key it uses for authentication with the HSM and store it in memory.

This flow has the advantage of not requiring human intervention should the instance reboot, which is highly advantageous if you have a power outage in a datacenter and the instances comprising your secure root of trust have all been restarted. They're each able to bootstrap themselves. 
 The disadvantage is that if someone had root access to this instance they could fetch the SRK secret and use that to decrypt and steal the private key used to contact the HSM, and subsequently get things signed that shouldn't be. Of course if they have root access to the instance they could pluck the key out of memory anyway. 

--
 About decrypting the vTPM: My gut feeling is If the vTPM decryption key is readily available on the hypervisor, then there's no point in encrypting the tpm in the first place. I suppose one option would be to require the vTPM be decrypted from within the VM /prior/ to it being provisioned or subsequently unlocked. I don't know how that'd work. 

Or perhaps the decryption key stored in barbican is good enough, and is fetched by the hypervisor as needed when the instance boots. I'll need to ask some of our security people to weigh in.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-11-01 20:11:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-11-01 20:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Re: Penick's comments about the master password and such on the TPM, I believe that is a separate topic from the secret used by libvirt for encryption. The VM is just given a "new" TPM, AIUI, just like if you unboxed a server and started an OS on it. Libvirt's vTPM secret secures the underlying data structure which holds the TPM's state.'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-11-01 20:34:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-01 21:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-11-04 14:54:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I get that nova could go get it from barbican, but I can't figure out how it's provided to libvirt.

That's documented in the libvirt docs[0]. 

> A secret may also be defined via the virSecretDefineXML API. Once the secret is defined, a secret value will need to be set. The secret would be the passphrase used to decrypt the vTPM state. The following is a simple example of using virsh secret-set-value to set the secret value. The virSecretSetValue API may also be used to set a more secure secret without using printable/readable characters.

[0] https://libvirt.org/formatsecret.html#vTPMUsageType"}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-11-04 14:55:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

My questions were answered.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-11 19:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Workflow-1

(35 comments)

In offline conversations we've decided to simplify a bit further by removing the backup/rebuild piece of this. The philosophy is that, when in doubt, this thing should pretty much behave like baremetal. E.g. if you restore a backup onto a baremetal box, the TPM stays in whatever state it was in most recently. If you restore onto a different box, you get a fresh (or no) TPM (more realistically in whatever state it was in just prior to the restore).

So we're only going to do the swift thing for shelve *offload* (because non-offloaded doesn't need it, because it's still on the host); and otherwise only support "moving" a vTPM for migration-y operations.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-12 00:48:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-12 00:48:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-04 18:03:53.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Spec: Ussuri: Emulated Virtual TPM

There are a class of applications which expect to use a TPM device to
store secrets. In order to run these applications in a virtual machine,
it would be useful to expose a virtual TPM device within the guest.
Accordingly, the suggestion is to add a placement resource which could
be requested in the flavor which would cause such a device to be added
to the VM.

Blueprint: add-emulated-virtual-tpm

Change-Id: I299903a5f3b3741cb2b2d0271087c263552d4134
Previously-approved: train
Previously-approved: stein

commit_message:
Spec: Ussuri: Encrypted Emulated Virtual TPM

There are a class of applications which expect to use a TPM device to
store secrets. In order to run these applications in a virtual machine,
it would be useful to expose a virtual TPM device within the guest.
This spec describes adding flavor/image properties which cause such a
device to be added to the VM.

Blueprint: add-emulated-virtual-tpm

Change-Id: I299903a5f3b3741cb2b2d0271087c263552d4134
Previously-approved: train
Previously-approved: stein

[1] https://79c3c05853049136fc77-8b23fb57107c099fc623f82f25f9ddb3.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/701794/1/check/nova-next/d3011a4/testr_results.html"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-09 21:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-10 14:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701797/ is not being accepted without granularly explicitly disabling the network on tests that don't need it, so given that requirement, this is the preferred solution."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-10 22:41:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-01-10 23:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

lgtm. this is more explicit, less work.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-11 03:09:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-11 16:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This seems to be working - the test patch has passed several times in a row with the latest rev.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-13 11:57:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

ghanshyam can you confim that this will have on effect on runing the test with a fixed network and ssh verifcation in either fixed or floating mode.

 i dont know enough about how tempest is implented to make that determination but i have deploy tempest in the past where i expcilty configured it to use a fixed precreted network in an env where we had a dedicated shared network that was routabel and no floating ips.

i also know that rackspace used to not expose the neutron api so when running tempest against there cloud you have do use the name of the network they precreated for you so while im in faovor of this generally i just want to check that this will not have any interoprablity issues?'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-13 14:23:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Sean, FWIW this isn't the first patch to introduce the default network to test cases, as you can see by the deltas where I replaced existing setup_credentials overrides with the class variable (e.g. [1]).

Of course that doesn't mean those precedents weren't wrong to begin with, or that it's okay for the new ones just because it's okay for those...

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701792/3/tempest/api/compute/admin/test_live_migration.py"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-13 14:30:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

ok as i said im generally in favor of this so ill change my vote to a +1 i just wanted a tempest person to confim it has not unintended sideefects like making it posible to run tempest with ironic and flat networks instead of neutron.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-01-13 14:35:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

tbc, I wasn't disagreeing with you @Sean, just giving a little more detail/context for gmann et al to answer with."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-01-13 17:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> ok as i said im generally in favor of this so ill change my vote to
 > a +1 i just wanted a tempest person to confim it has not unintended
 > sideefects like making it posible to run tempest with ironic and
 > flat networks instead of neutron.

There is no side effect of this change actually. For both way, pre-provisioned cred and dymanic credential we can still configure Tempest to use the fixed_network_name for server creation. 

1. Pre-provisioned cred - we can always specifiy the exact network name per proejcts/users to use for tests. If not set, then fixed_network_name will be used for all server creations.

2. Dynamic cred (this changes)  - Default behaviour of Tempest is supposed to create isloated network for each server creation. User can configure is to use the fixed_network_name for all server creation with setting below two config options (which is what ironic jobs are setting):
1. CONF.auth.create_isolated_networks = False. This will prevent the dymanic cred to create default networks for server creation even test ask for the network creation[1].

2. CONF.compute.fixed_network_name-  test.py will assign this network to server creation request as no default tenant network is there due to first option[2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/b63725301488a910d2ad5e1a3f8a11b45b187845/tempest/common/credentials_factory.py#L87

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/b63725301488a910d2ad5e1a3f8a11b45b187845/tempest/lib/common/fixed_network.py#L96'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-13 19:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

great thanks for confiming.

i have had cause to use those options to restict how the test execute in the past but never dug deep enough to see how the are implemented in the test code.'}, {'account_id': 5689, 'date': '2020-01-14 09:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

lgtm'}]

commit_message:
Create default network for several compute tests

Chipping away at the referenced bug, this commit introduces a
class-level variable on BaseV2ComputeTest that triggers
setup_credentials to create a default network, and sets it for several
classes where the problem has been observed. The class variable is so we
can whack-a-mole with one line instead of four whenever this problem
pops up.

Change-Id: Ia34fe3b41261de02918713c2a948e6c56554bf6f
Partial-Bug: #1844568

commit_message:
functional: Make '_IntegratedTestBase' subclass 'InstanceHelperMixin'

This means we can drop many duplicate implementations of things

- nova.tests.function.integrated_helpers._IntegratedTestBase

  - _build_minimal_create_server_request

- nova.tests.functional.test_servers.ServersTestBase

  - _wait_for_server_parameter
  - _wait_for_state_change
  - _wait_until_deleted

Change-Id: I0d21cb94c932e6e556eca964c57868c705b2d120
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix permission error if Barbican is enabled for Swift

The config files need to be relabled too avoid permission errors, otherwise
the Barbican key ID is not set and Swift fails to start.

Closes-Bug: 1858845
Change-Id: Idb94fee8aee1de3b1c7338108ccd8b45b6f169bf
(cherry picked from commit 77b48f39888436bb6d463aa89290fce27f074870)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-25 01:46:20.000000000', 'message': 'Scheduler a vm to a reporting compute node

When scheduling a vm to a reporting compute node,
update_available_resource will clear self.stats and update compute_nodes
table in db firstly, and update this table after calculating all
instances on this node. At this moment, the scheduler filter will pass
this node because there is no num_instances in compute_nodes.stats.

Change-Id: Iffe8eaf009c62d34bbe703b39c802dce69d74c81
Closes-Bug:#1857448
'}, {'created': '2020-01-03 01:10:22.000000000', 'message': 'preserve num_instances during update_available_resource

During the execution of the update_available_resource perodic task the num_instances value is reset and saved to the db while the task is running. As a result the NumInstancesFilter can allow hosts to pass that would otherwise be rejected due to the incorrect data. This change preserves the number of instances running on the host while the periodic task completes.

Change-Id: Iffe8eaf009c62d34bbe703b39c802dce69d74c81
Closes-Bug:#1857448
'}, {'created': '2020-01-03 01:12:49.000000000', 'message': 'preserve num_instances during update_available_resource

During the execution of the update_available_resource
perodic task the num_instances value is reset and
saved to the db while the task is running. As a result
the NumInstancesFilter can allow hosts to pass that
would otherwise be rejected due to the incorrect data.
This change preserves the number of instances running
on the host while the periodic task completes.

Change-Id: Iffe8eaf009c62d34bbe703b39c802dce69d74c81
Closes-Bug:#1857448
'}]
commit_message:
preserve num_instances during update_available_resource

During the execution of the update_available_resource
perodic task the num_instances value is reset and
saved to the db while the task is running. As a result
the NumInstancesFilter can allow hosts to pass that
would otherwise be rejected due to the incorrect data.
This change preserves the number of instances running
on the host while the periodic task completes.

Change-Id: Iffe8eaf009c62d34bbe703b39c802dce69d74c81
Closes-Bug:#1857448

commit_message:
Ensure network leftovers without kuryrnet CRD obj are deleted

This patch ensures that network leftovers without kuryrnet CRD
object associated (caused by crash/restart of the kuryr-controller
at an unfortunate time) are also handled by the cleanup thread
triggered at the kuryr-controller restart.

Change-Id: Id1d036b80438b21a100be12282058b995c36d2c3
Closes-Bug: 1856843
(cherry picked from commit db3fcbb8b49bc728ef32c8b0677696e360c1db9a)

[{'created': '2020-01-09 12:09:12.000000000', 'message': "Add 'never' to the tags set for the Ceph systemd units migration task

The systemd units migration should only happen once, when explicitly
called by tripleoclient using --tags ceph_systemd

Also renames the old ceph-systemd tag into ceph_systemd tag for
consistency and to prevent issues when passing the tag name as argument
from the command line.

Change-Id: I9387885a57f8532b414485bc2919eb33aeadf52b
Closes-Bug: 1859009
"}]
commit_message:
Add 'never' to the tags set for the Ceph systemd units migration task

The systemd units migration should only happen once, when explicitly
called by tripleoclient using --tags ceph_systemd

Also renames the old ceph-systemd tag into ceph_systemd tag for
consistency and to prevent issues when passing the tag name as argument
from the command line.

Change-Id: I9387885a57f8532b414485bc2919eb33aeadf52b
Closes-Bug: 1859009

commit_message:
CNI: handle delete when db record is missing

We should let DEL request to succeed even if the DB record is not
found in database. In this case, we cannot retrieve the vif thus
ignoring the vif disconnect step.

Change-Id: I8207d7b624af17ddf002affb626cc4f1d8bdabec

commit_message:
Disable unbound in OpenDev CI

OpenDev runs unbound on ubuntu bionic nodes, which provides
ipv6 preferred responses to applications.

This unfortunately prevents dnsmasq from launching,
so stopping the service for testing purposes.

Change-Id: I8c1fc1d056c53681562685646b0f78d9bdbcce39

commit_message:
Remove upload_validations workflow execution

The 'tripleo.validations.v1.upload_validations' workflow has been
removed from tripleo-common, this Undercloud post installation step
could be safely removed.

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-23 09:43:50.000000000', 'message': 'Generate plugin registry based on releases repo

The plugin registry is maintained manually, so it tends to be out-of-date.
The deliverble files in openstack/releases repository provide information
on repositories and bug trackers. It sounds reasonable to me to generate
the plugin registry based on infomration in the openstack/releases repo.

The script added picks up deliverables marked as horizon-plugin.
mistral-dashboard and networking-bgpvpn dashboard are released in
different ways, so they are handled specially in the script.

How to run:
  ./tools/list-horizon-plugins.py \
      --csv-file plugin-registry.csv \
      ../releases ussuri

Note that this commit does not autogenerate the plugin registry.
The script still needs to be run manually.
Further automation would be the next step.

Note that bug trackers of senlin-dashboard and trove-dashboard in
the releases repo looks out-of-date. I will submit a fix for them soon.

The downside of the automation is that we cannot list non-official
horizon plugins but I believe it is a good compromise.
The only non-offical plugin listed now is the group-based-policy UI,
but it is questionable whether it is still maintained well.

Change-Id: Id56be13fb93c6dc123e7cfb1c906357cdf59732b
'}]
commit_message:
Generate plugin registry based on releases repo

The plugin registry is maintained manually, so it tends to be out-of-date.
The deliverble files in openstack/releases repository provide information
on repositories and bug trackers. It sounds reasonable to me to generate
the plugin registry based on infomration in the openstack/releases repo.

The script added picks up deliverables marked as horizon-plugin.
mistral-dashboard and networking-bgpvpn dashboard are released in
different ways, so they are handled specially in the script.

How to run:
  ./tools/list-horizon-plugins.py \
      --csv-file plugin-registry.csv \
      ../releases ussuri

Note that this commit does not autogenerate the plugin registry.
The script still needs to be run manually.
Further automation would be the next step.

Note that bug trackers of senlin-dashboard and trove-dashboard in
the releases repo looks out-of-date. I will submit a fix for them soon.

The downside of the automation is that we cannot list non-official
horizon plugins but I believe it is a good compromise.
The only non-offical plugin listed now is the group-based-policy UI,
but it is questionable whether it is still maintained well.

Change-Id: Id56be13fb93c6dc123e7cfb1c906357cdf59732b

commit_message:
Update json module to jsonutils

oslo project provide jsonutils, and the others use it in many place,
this PS to update the json module to oslo jsonutils for consistency.

Change-Id: Ie8bdc41e420fbbbafaca7d7eaeaa702d93c6a18d

commit_message:
Cap hacking, add bindep.txt and update sphinx requirement

This is a combination of 3 fixes, which are all needed to fix the gate.

1. Adjust version constraint of hacking

Neutron constrained the version of hacking < 1.2.0, but since then the
unit tests fails with:

ERROR: Double requirement given: hacking<1.2.0,>=1.1.0 (from -ri https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/raw/branch/master/test-requirements.txt (line 4)) (already in hacking>=1.1.0 (from -r [..]networking-powervm/test-requirements.txt (line 4)), name='hacking')

So let's simply use the same constraint as set in neutron.

2. Add bindep.txt

...to fix building lxml

(cherry picked from commit ed11ef916d415ea060ca92afa0521f863714ffec)

3. Update sphinx version constraints

Since we touch requirements file with this patch the requirements-check
job also runs and does not find the matching python2 and python3 sphinx
requirements, so update that.

Change-Id: Ic4d97db6c947264806e5ef9e35f21f764cbecf46
(cherry picked from commit a00fc731b14bd3ef953fe4cffdc74c8e441c0e13)
(cherry picked from commit 032cd43638fa190aa26ca564b71f293de7a74bb9)

In LP#1830574, we introduce the dracut command to include necessary
file into initramfs. However, dracut in RHEL or CentOS doesn't include
sysctl.conf or other specific module related confs at an installation
of new kernel if dracut-config-generic package exists on the system.

We should remove the package to allow creating a host-specific initramfs
at an installation of new kernel.

Change-Id: Ib1618b873ec6640c79291388d4ebc95283688b8c
Closes-bug: #1857493
"}]
commit_message:
Remove dracut-config-generic package

In LP#1830574, we introduce the dracut command to include necessary
file into initramfs. However, dracut in RHEL or CentOS doesn't include
sysctl.conf or other specific module related confs at an installation
of new kernel if dracut-config-generic package exists on the system.

We should remove the package to allow creating a host-specific initramfs
at an installation of new kernel.

Change-Id: Ib1618b873ec6640c79291388d4ebc95283688b8c
Closes-bug: #1857493

These fields exist in the database, and we should let the user see it.

commit_message:
Allow reading root_device from instance_info

For the future deployment API we need to be able to set root_device
per deployment in addition to per node. This change adds it.

Change-Id: I1dd046c2e5fca211a84290bac8daa7550b21614f
Story: #2006910
Task: #37955

commit_message:
Fix flake8 tox.ini directive

Do not specify posargs on flake8 line in pep8 section, as it
breaks using 'tox -e pep8 HEAD~1' to check just code changed
in current change. While here change to match octavia tree
regarding enabled extensions.

Also fixed basepython warning now generated after removing
python2 code.

Trivialfix

Change-Id: Ib4326a1947845a229418b6b4213efc9f2bb12b32

subject: Add retries to update trunk port
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1131, 'name': 'Brian Haley', 'email': 'haleyb.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-haley'}, {'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 9732, 'name': 'Mellanox CI', 'email': 'mlnx-openstack-ci@dev.mellanox.co.il', 'username': 'mellanox', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 9845, 'name': 'Arista CI', 'email': 'arista-openstack-test@aristanetworks.com', 'username': 'arista-test', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 11975, 'name': 'Slawek Kaplonski', 'email': 'skaplons@redhat.com', 'username': 'slaweq'}, {'_account_id': 13995, 'name': 'Nate Johnston', 'email': 'nate.johnston@redhat.com', 'username': 'natejohnston'}, {'_account_id': 15554, 'name': 'Bence Romsics', 'email': 'bence.romsics@gmail.com', 'username': 'ebenrom'}, {'_account_id': 16688, 'name': 'Rodolfo Alonso', 'email': 'ralonsoh@redhat.com', 'username': 'rodolfo-alonso-hernandez'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26622, 'name': 'Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI', 'email': 'neutron_hyperv_ci@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'neutron_hyperv_ci'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-12-12 11:35:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-12-12 12:31:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This retry situation is not ideal, but I still don't know how to do this better.

To the best of my understanding it is possible to lose trunk status updates, if racing and re-tried status updates overwrite each other's results. Which is getting more likely to happen in reality if you started seeing StaleDataErrors coming from updates to *different* trunk statuses.

One direction I never explored yet is this: We could try to reduce the number of rpc messages coming from the agent to lower the concurrency of trunk related updates in the server. I'm not sure if I remember correctly but I think we receive one message per subport - which we could theoretically batch up when we have lots of subports to process. On the other hand what could be batched up is likely dependent on how the trunk API is used - where we may not have control.

I'm just thinking out loud, I did not look at this other direction deeply. Doing the retry I think is better than not doing it, so I'm leaving +1.

Side question: If you know the client calling neutron when you get StaleDataErrors: How many subports does it add in one API call? One, many, all? It it adds one per call, can you experiment with changing it to many or all?"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-12-12 13:23:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This retry situation is not ideal, but I still don't know how to do
 > this better.
 > 
 > To the best of my understanding it is possible to lose trunk status
 > updates, if racing and re-tried status updates overwrite each
 > other's results. Which is getting more likely to happen in reality
 > if you started seeing StaleDataErrors coming from updates to
 > *different* trunk statuses.
 > 
 > One direction I never explored yet is this: We could try to reduce
 > the number of rpc messages coming from the agent to lower the
 > concurrency of trunk related updates in the server. I'm not sure if
 > I remember correctly but I think we receive one message per subport

during my tests today and yesterday, I noticed that when I created 3 subports in batch (openstack network trunk set --subport ... --subport ... --subport ... <trunk_id>) agent sent it to neutron server in one rpc call.

 > - which we could theoretically batch up when we have lots of
 > subports to process. On the other hand what could be batched up is
 > likely dependent on how the trunk API is used - where we may not
 > have control.
 > 
 > I'm just thinking out loud, I did not look at this other direction
 > deeply. Doing the retry I think is better than not doing it, so I'm
 > leaving +1.
 > 
 > Side question: If you know the client calling neutron when you get
 > StaleDataErrors: How many subports does it add in one API call?
 > One, many, all? It it adds one per call, can you experiment with
 > changing it to many or all?"}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-12-12 17:04:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/698698/1 : SUCCESS in 2h 11m 52s'}, {'account_id': 15554, 'date': '2019-12-13 09:52:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> during my tests today and yesterday, I noticed that when I created
 > 3 subports in batch (openstack network trunk set --subport ...
 > --subport ... --subport ... <trunk_id>) agent sent it to neutron
 > server in one rpc call.

That's good, because that means we can reduce the frequency of this problem on the client side too. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2020-01-13 14:48:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-01-13 15:24:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2020-01-13 18:05:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-01-14 08:06:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/train as commit 8ec0c2d8658acd6fb0aaf80751914514bdb42334'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-12 11:35:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add retries to update trunk port

In [1] retry of trunk update was added to avoid StaleDataError
exceptions to fail to set trunk port or subports to ACTIVE state.
But it was only partial fix for the issue descibed in related bug
and from [2] we know that it still can happen on high load systems
from time to time.
So I was checking this issue and reported bug again and I found out
that retry was added only in _process_trunk_subport_bindings()
method. But StaleDataError can be raised also in other cases where
the same trunk is updated, e.g. in update_trunk_status() method.

So this commit adds same retry mechanism to all trunk.update() actions
in services.trunk.rpc.server module.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662236/
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1733197

Change-Id: I10e3619d5f3600ea97ed695321bb691dece3181f
Partial-Bug: #1828375
'}]
commit_message:
Add retries to update trunk port

In [1] retry of trunk update was added to avoid StaleDataError
exceptions to fail to set trunk port or subports to ACTIVE state.
But it was only partial fix for the issue descibed in related bug
and from [2] we know that it still can happen on high load systems
from time to time.
So I was checking this issue and reported bug again and I found out
that retry was added only in _process_trunk_subport_bindings()
method. But StaleDataError can be raised also in other cases where
the same trunk is updated, e.g. in update_trunk_status() method.

So this commit adds same retry mechanism to all trunk.update() actions
in services.trunk.rpc.server module.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662236/
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1733197

Change-Id: I10e3619d5f3600ea97ed695321bb691dece3181f
Partial-Bug: #1828375

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Added security group rule provider class

Puppet Neutron can manage Neutron security group rule.

Removing security group rule and unit tests - WIP

Change-Id: I79c69fe5b98751791f2cd466c9561d46e1029b9f
Co-Authored-By: Daniel Pawlik <daniel.pawlik@corp.ovh.com>
Closes-Bug: #1671474

Hacking received a major update to version 2.0.0 that added new checks
that fail on stable branches. Instead of addressing those new check
errors on stable branches, it is better to cap hacking to <2. This way

(cherry picked from commit 85f7abbbaf958458ee12415b0de0e938c20fb121)

commit_message:
Cap hacking version to <2

Hacking received a major update to version 2.0.0 that added new checks
that fail on stable branches. Instead of addressing those new check
errors on stable branches, it is better to cap hacking to <2. This way
we'll not see lint errors again should new checks be added in the
future.

Support for hacking 2.0.0 in master branch is being worked in
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699302/

commit_message:
Cap hacking version to <2

Hacking received a major update to version 2.0.0 that added new checks
that fail on stable branches. Instead of addressing those new check
errors on stable branches, it is better to cap hacking to <2. This way
we'll not see lint errors again should new checks be added in the
future.

Support for hacking 2.0.0 in master branch is being worked in
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/699302/

Change-Id: I4706972095d42815a3f3cec0bc5aa82a34922bf3
(cherry picked from commit 85f7abbbaf958458ee12415b0de0e938c20fb121)
(cherry picked from commit d0ef7a823150ea84e0fbb8d54711dfbe8fb9e477)

commit_message:
copy-wheels: ensure split actually splits

From the ansible manual

"The difference between single quotes and double quotes is that in
double quotes you can use escapes:"

This turns out to be important when you're splitting based on \n ...

Change-Id: Ia033426bf05a63034fb11882e92d29e3ede8fc53

commit_message:

commit_message:
Relax filtering in krb-service-principals jinja

The filtering added to fix Bug: #1821377 filters any
network without a VIP address. This filtering is to
agressive and cause deployment failure when a management
network without a VIP is used.

Change-Id: If189eb6fc0b2dc2c78323a7c08f7e303be2b6124
Resolves: rhbz#1778719
Closes-Bug: #1854846
(cherry picked from commit af79ae34ad9a3ed1581c0f6df91fa1e3ef0f8433)

[{'created': '2019-12-27 20:32:44.000000000', 'message': 'Retry a few times on listing extensions

Listing neutron extensions is part of the startup process.
During system reboot, kuryr-libnetwork process might start before
the neutron processes, which leads to failure on listing neutron
extensions thus failing the kuryr process.

We need to be robust on startup. This commit will retry a few
times on listing extensions to handle this case.

Change-Id: I18a2a6c057225e30ba7e03e1377ab88884d8d2bd
Related-Bug: #1850936
(cherry picked from commit 97266ff5b904db5bd89930ff8fa7bc4ba3506ebe)
'}]
commit_message:
Retry a few times on listing extensions

Listing neutron extensions is part of the startup process.
During system reboot, kuryr-libnetwork process might start before
the neutron processes, which leads to failure on listing neutron
extensions thus failing the kuryr process.

We need to be robust on startup. This commit will retry a few
times on listing extensions to handle this case.

Change-Id: I18a2a6c057225e30ba7e03e1377ab88884d8d2bd
Related-Bug: #1850936
(cherry picked from commit 97266ff5b904db5bd89930ff8fa7bc4ba3506ebe)

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

'}, {'created': '2020-01-05 12:29:25.000000000', 'message': 'Show correct name for resource with quota set to zero

In case quota for the resource is set to zero "openstack quota show"
command will not map the resource name according to one of the
following dicts:
 - COMPUTE_QUOTAS
 - NOVA_NETWORK_QUOTAS
 - VOLUME_QUOTAS
 - NETWORK_QUOTAS

For example:
$ openstack quota set --secgroups 10 admin
$ openstack quota show admin -f json|egrep "(secgroups|security_groups)"

$ openstack quota set --secgroups 0 admin
$ openstack quota show admin -f json|egrep "(secgroups|security_groups)"
  "security_groups": 0,

 - VOLUME_QUOTAS
 - NETWORK_QUOTAS

For example:
$ openstack quota set --secgroups 10 admin
$ openstack quota show admin -f json|egrep "(secgroups|security_groups)"
  "secgroups": 10,
$ openstack quota set --secgroups 0 admin
$ openstack quota show admin -f json|egrep "(secgroups|security_groups)"

commit_message:
Show correct name for resource with quota set to zero

In case quota for the resource is set to zero "openstack quota show"
command will not map the resource name according to one of the
following dicts:
 - COMPUTE_QUOTAS
 - NOVA_NETWORK_QUOTAS
 - VOLUME_QUOTAS
 - NETWORK_QUOTAS

For example:
$ openstack quota set --secgroups 10 admin
$ openstack quota show admin -f json|egrep "(secgroups|security_groups)"
  "secgroups": 10,
$ openstack quota set --secgroups 0 admin
$ openstack quota show admin -f json|egrep "(secgroups|security_groups)"
  "security_groups": 0,

Change-Id: I94ed9e6b41b1cc692297c01e6c7582998dcacfda

commit_message:
Modify import_role to include_role for boot params service

Using static import_role, make the vars defined under the
import_role task to be available for the whole PLAY itself,
which is causing the role-specific parameter to be available
in other roles. Move to dynamic include_role, which will
define these variables only for the included ansible role.
Closes-Bug: #1859129

Change-Id: I402db858526def9dfd33f954f1ecd885c01f4367

commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2. requirements.txt and
lower-constraints.txt are updated accordingly. for more info. please
refer [1].
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enable_Django22_support_in_Horizon_Plugin

Change-Id: If7c7ce79594449637655c4832db50c2c243ce1c0
