commit_message:
Fix wheel index generation

What I didn't notice is that on disk the projects are in a/ b/ c/ type
subdirectories, while from the mirror side we paper-over this with
mod_rewrite rules so the projects all look like they're at top-level.

This should make the script descend into each directory correctly to
generate the index.

Change-Id: I89d255e2bcd5b5c86a33dec1a77086c97bde4c7a

subject: Introduce bandit security linter
messages:
[{'account_id': 24872, 'date': '2019-12-25 10:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-12-26 02:11:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Using static analysis for security is a good idea. Also, other projects like Nova are using bandit [1]. However, I have some questions whether bandit is the best tool for the job, and whether we should investigate other tools.

* Bandit may apparently generate many false positives [1], i.e., report issues that don't exist. In fact, there is evidence that Nova hit that issue [3]. One can apparently suppress false positives using '# nosec' comments, but:
  * that still requires some developer thought and discussion for that, and
  * #nosec can suppress real issues, as [2] says.

* There are alternatives like pysa from Facebook [4]. Has anybody looked into that? It works differently: while bandit uses AST, pysa uses control/data flow graphs, which can be more accurate. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/14872caae1a51c7015dd7c509d0173df2e943ed4/tox.ini#L215
[2] https://smarketshq.com/avoiding-injection-with-taint-analysis-1e55429e207b
[3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1701712
[4] https://pyre-check.org/docs/pysa-basics.html"}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-12-26 02:24:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> * Bandit may apparently generate many false positives [1], i.e.,

Oops, meant [2].

 > [2] https://smarketshq.com/avoiding-injection-with-taint-analysis-1e55429e207b'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2019-12-26 07:00:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> Using static analysis for security is a good idea. Also, other
 > projects like Nova are using bandit [1]. However, I have some
 > questions whether bandit is the best tool for the job, and whether
 > we should investigate other tools.
 > 
 > * Bandit may apparently generate many false positives [1], i.e.,
 > report issues that don't exist. In fact, there is evidence that
 > Nova hit that issue [3]. One can apparently suppress false
 > positives using '# nosec' comments, but:
 > * that still requires some developer thought and discussion for
 > that, and
 > * #nosec can suppress real issues, as [2] says.
 > 
 > * There are alternatives like pysa from Facebook [4]. Has anybody
 > looked into that? It works differently: while bandit uses AST, pysa
 > uses control/data flow graphs, which can be more accurate.
 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/14872caae1a51c7015dd7c509d0173df2e943ed4/tox.ini#L215
 > [2] https://smarketshq.com/avoiding-injection-with-taint-analysis-1e55429e207b
 > [3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1701712
 > [4] https://pyre-check.org/docs/pysa-basics.html

Hi Sundar, I think add a tool to check the code and make the code more security, or ever not more security just make the code more standard, is always a good thing.

-1 is to the setting, checked the log, the tests files didn't been ingored, should setting like below to ingore the tests files:
commands = bandit -r cyborg -x cyborg/tests/* -n 5 -ll"}, {'account_id': 24872, 'date': '2019-12-26 09:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to security_check_with_bandit'}, {'account_id': 24872, 'date': '2019-12-30 06:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2020-01-02 01:34:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-03 03:29:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2020-01-03 06:56:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Hi Sundar, I think add a tool to check the code and make the code
 > more security, or ever not more security just make the code more
 > standard, is always a good thing.

Of course, security is good. My question was, whether bandit is the best tool for that. No objections if everybody else agrees to it, or there is no data to choose a better tool.'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2020-01-04 01:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 24872, 'date': '2020-01-06 03:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 24872, 'date': '2020-01-06 03:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

Thanks chenker for the review!
pls see the update.'}, {'account_id': 24872, 'date': '2020-01-06 06:44:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Using static analysis for security is a good idea. Also, other
 > projects like Nova are using bandit [1]. However, I have some
 > questions whether bandit is the best tool for the job, and whether
 > we should investigate other tools.
 > 
 > * Bandit may apparently generate many false positives [1], i.e.,
 > report issues that don't exist. In fact, there is evidence that
 > Nova hit that issue [3]. One can apparently suppress false
 > positives using '# nosec' comments, but:
 > * that still requires some developer thought and discussion for
 > that, and
 > * #nosec can suppress real issues, as [2] says.
 > 
 > * There are alternatives like pysa from Facebook [4]. Has anybody
 > looked into that? It works differently: while bandit uses AST, pysa
 > uses control/data flow graphs, which can be more accurate.
 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/14872caae1a51c7015dd7c509d0173df2e943ed4/tox.ini#L215
 > [2] https://smarketshq.com/avoiding-injection-with-taint-analysis-1e55429e207b
 > [3] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1701712
 > [4] https://pyre-check.org/docs/pysa-basics.html

Hi Sundar, not yet looked into other tools except bandit.
seems pysa also does type check, as is said on its official page: "Pyre is a fast, scalable type checker for large Python 3 codebases, designed to help improve code quality and development speed by flagging type errors interactively in your terminal or favorite editor. We follow the typing standards introduced in PEP484 and PEP526." Will be that too much for us? It's an urgent need to have a security check before production usage of cyborg. Bandit is simple and makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2020-01-06 23:03:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Hi Sundar, not yet looked into other tools except bandit.

OK

 > seems pysa also does type check, as is said on its official page:
 > ...
 >  Will be that too much for us? 

My understanding is pyre does type checking but pysa is a subset that only does static analysis. 

Looks like none of us have experience or done studies on alternatives. So, let's go with bandit for now."}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-07 02:01:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Ye. Let's go with bandit check. if there is a better one in the future, we can introduce it again."}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-07 02:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2020-01-07 04:50:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Let others also review.'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2020-01-14 03:28:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

may be insecure. Current "sudo lspci -nnn -D" in huawei ascend driver code[0]
is insecure, but there is no any job/test that can check the potential security

commit_message:
Introduce bandit security linter

Cyborg now does not have a code security check, which may connive at
possible security issues. For example, shell-related operations for drivers
may be insecure. Current "sudo lspci -nnn -D" in huawei ascend driver code[0]
is insecure, but there is no any job/test that can check the potential security
issues. So this patch introduces bandit as a code security check.

[0]:https://github.com/openstack/cyborg/blob/master/cyborg/accelerator/drivers/aichip/huawei/ascend.py#L69

Change-Id: Ia1f9acbbd176180cb5fe97b1a2eee5f98a95dea6

commit_message:
Return the right block size

When copy volume with path, transfer block size from MB to bytes,
but still return block size in MB. This patch fix it.

Change-Id: I795cbb7016f7d7ce257706ba8b5e0ba8214fbc90

(2 comments)

Hi Sundar, please see my reply inline.'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2019-12-16 05:45:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 30759, 'date': '2019-12-19 03:59:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Hi Xinran, thank you for your patch. 

Your suggested curl command works well, but there are some miss-match with the format of openstacksdk's list function.
List function in openstacksdk[1] posts the GET method like below,but this patch can't parse this, and outputs error.

curl -g -i -X GET "http://HOST_IP:6666/v2/devices?type=FPGA".
Result : BadRequestException: 400: Client Error for url: http://HOST_IP:6666/v2/devices?type=FPGA, Unknown argument: "type" 

For example, current client patch using openstacksdk posts GET method like below:
# openstack accelerator device list --type FPGA --vendor 0xABCD
->  curl -g -i -X GET "http://HOST_IP:6666/v2/devices?vendor=0xABCD&type=FPGA" 

Could you consider the fitting to the spec?
(Of course, I can help that work.)

[1]https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/resource.py#L1538'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2019-12-24 06:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Hi Xinran, thank you for your patch.
 > 
 > Your suggested curl command works well, but there are some
 > miss-match with the format of openstacksdk's list function.

 > below,but this patch can't parse this, and outputs error.
 > 
 > curl -g -i -X GET "http://HOST_IP:6666/v2/devices?type=FPGA".
 > Result : BadRequestException: 400: Client Error for url:
 > http://HOST_IP:6666/v2/devices?type=FPGA, Unknown argument: "type"
 > 
 > For example, current client patch using openstacksdk posts GET
 > method like below:
 > # openstack accelerator device list --type FPGA --vendor 0xABCD
 > ->  curl -g -i -X GET "http://HOST_IP:6666/v2/devices?vendor=0xABCD&type=FPGA"
 > 
 > Could you consider the fitting to the spec?
 > (Of course, I can help that work.)
 > 
 > [1]https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/resource.py#L1538

Hi Shoga, thanks for your comments, please see this TODO https://github.com/openstack/cyborg/blob/master/cyborg/api/controllers/v1/deployables.py#L169, it said will remove limit, marker, sort_key, sort_dir, so I supposed that we should support all filter's param in "filters" params including type and vendor_id. How do you think about it, shall we improve cyborgclient to accept "filters" with all params?'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2019-12-27 07:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2019-12-30 03:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Implementation of Device v2 API

The v2 API spec has been merged https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658263/
This patch aims at:
1. Implement v2 Device list, show APIs which is a dependency of Horizon-Cyborg
intergration part.
2. Polish device fake data used by test cases.

The disable/enable API will be implemented later.

Change-Id: Ie1c363d3be68d31357f2a980fc33b88a20bfb146
Task: 37591
Story: 2006923

commit_message:
Supporting multipart request to allow file object

cgi  module was having issue https://bugs.python.org/issue27777
due to use of tempfile.TemporaryFile("wb") ranger_agent_api needed
readOnlyRootFilesystem: false

Change-Id: Ia010627c931ed2765ea7d95e183e69ade5ab8f25

I do not prefer any on them. 
Both is OK for me.
Even we use python stand NotFound Exception. It is a generic one.


But the Exception is used for User, they used it for debug when errors during their operations. 
Why not let users to vote it?'}, {'account_id': 14131, 'date': '2020-01-03 04:31:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Another things we should put too much energy on this.

These kind bugs will be found easily when we add UT.

You can see the example:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700504 

I put these bugs and other improvement together in one patch and the UT can covers them. 

It is better to put more energy on UT.'}, {'account_id': 14131, 'date': '2020-01-03 04:32:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I guess user like specific exceptions. :)'}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-07 01:39:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

 > I put these bugs and other improvement together in one patch and

 >

 > Both is OK for me.
 > Even we use python stand NotFound Exception. It is a generic one.
 > 
 > 
 > But the Exception is used for User, they used it for debug when
 > errors during their operations.
 > Why not let users to vote it?
Hi Shaohe. In this way, no change is seen from the user's perspective. But for us, we can improve the positioning of code bugs. I think it is worthwhile to change. Regarding UT, it is a more important task and will continue to be optimized."}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-07 06:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-08 08:18:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2020-01-08 08:30:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2020-01-10 01:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Use ResourceNotFound replace DeviceProfileNotFound

This is a series of optimization for exception.

In fact, we only need to use the ResourceNotFound exception
to fit NotFound Exception.

Story: 2007045
Task: 37860

Change-Id: Ic1cbee1b6794cdd66d7749d54700466a2911abf8

messages:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-22 01:53:04.000000000', 'message': '[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

freezer-dr is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

freezer-dr is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Change-Id: I8c2e92f459c6a0fda26b44039837bd95db55873e

commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2. requirements.txt and
lower-constraints.txt are updated accordingly. for more info. please
refer [1].
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enable_Django22_support_in_Horizon_Plugin

Change-Id: Iea3bfeba70fc91c4c5b3f5741111dcd5afa5b324

commit_message:
Remove six usage

This repo does not support Python 2 anymore, so we don't need
six for compatibility between Python2 and 3, convert six usage to Python
3 code.

Note that six.text_type is "str" in Python 3, so we can remove the
clause completly.

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/701743
Change-Id: I7dbdf7b773d72db9204c6251b1ce561cf7675522

commit_message:
Drop unittest2 usage

unittest2 was needed for Python versions <= 2.6, so it has not been
needed for quite some time now. See unittest2 note on:

https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html

This drops unittest2 in favor of the standard unittest package.

Change-Id: Idb4cb10509f49afe86bfdb688e35a7822dfe38bd
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

subject: Don't mirror wheels for pip/setuptools/virtualenv
messages: [{'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2020-01-13 15:37:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2020-01-13 15:41:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-01-13 15:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-13 15:37:23.000000000', 'message': "Don't mirror wheels for pip/setuptools/virtualenv

A recent 45.0.0 release of Setuptools dropped support for (the now
EOL) Python 2.7 interpreter. It publishes to PyPI with
options.python_requires set to >=3.5 in its setup.cfg which causes
PyPI's simple index to serve that via a data-requires-python
attribute (see PEP 503) so that pip knows not to pick that one on
unsupported interpreters. Our wheel cache is just served via Apache
with mod_autoindex for its file listing, so lacks an ability to
convey this information.

In the short term, stop copying new versions of the pip, setuptools
and virtialenv wheels into the cache we publish, so that we can
safely remove broken versions of them manually and not have to worry
about them reappearing. Longer term, it may make sense to filter out
any wheels with manylinux or none-any platform specifiers, since
those the first absolutely exist on PyPI already or and the second
are trivial to build at job runtime if they don't. We really only
care about making sure we serve platform-specific wheels we've
built, as those will save the most time in jobs.

Change-Id: I02fac6beef9bb94cdeb1d0a84774c1b93357deb1
"}]
commit_message:
Don't mirror wheels for pip/setuptools/virtualenv

A recent 45.0.0 release of Setuptools dropped support for (the now
EOL) Python 2.7 interpreter. It publishes to PyPI with
options.python_requires set to >=3.5 in its setup.cfg which causes
PyPI's simple index to serve that via a data-requires-python
attribute (see PEP 503) so that pip knows not to pick that one on
unsupported interpreters. Our wheel cache is just served via Apache
with mod_autoindex for its file listing, so lacks an ability to
convey this information.

In the short term, stop copying new versions of the pip, setuptools
and virtialenv wheels into the cache we publish, so that we can
safely remove broken versions of them manually and not have to worry
about them reappearing. Longer term, it may make sense to filter out
any wheels with manylinux or none-any platform specifiers, since
those the first absolutely exist on PyPI already or and the second
are trivial to build at job runtime if they don't. We really only
care about making sure we serve platform-specific wheels we've
built, as those will save the most time in jobs.

Change-Id: I02fac6beef9bb94cdeb1d0a84774c1b93357deb1

subject: Adds bandit nosec flag to hashlib.sha1
messages: [{'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2020-01-13 20:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-01-13 20:57:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2020-01-14 01:28:18.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nCombined https://review.opendev.org/#/c/702262/ as we need both of them to pass all the gates.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-13 20:53:55.000000000', 'message': 'Adds bandit nosec flag to hashlib.sha1

A bandit patch to block sha1 hash is failing CI [1], due to a false
positive on hashlib.sha1 (which actually uses HMAC-SHA1 in keystone
that is considered more secure then standard SHA1)

This change marks a # nosec comment against the line which is
triggering the false positive in Bandit.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/437563/6

Change-Id: Ib9618119c77f41fba0e612e37c7511676bed47e8
(cherry picked from commit b29f478f28c4989156cfe87392cbd308e3f55c1e)
'}]
commit_message:
Adds bandit nosec flag to hashlib.sha1

A bandit patch to block sha1 hash is failing CI [1], due to a false
positive on hashlib.sha1 (which actually uses HMAC-SHA1 in keystone
that is considered more secure then standard SHA1)

This change marks a # nosec comment against the line which is
triggering the false positive in Bandit.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/437563/6

Change-Id: Ib9618119c77f41fba0e612e37c7511676bed47e8
(cherry picked from commit b29f478f28c4989156cfe87392cbd308e3f55c1e)

commit_message:
Fix python36 job setup

The Zuul template openstack-python3-ussuri-jobs-horizon includes
python36 job as voting in both check and gate.

Remove the ancient overwrite of non-voting in check queue. The job is
running fine and can be voting - as it's voting in gate already thanks
to the template.

later in tripleo deploy.

Closes-Bug: #1859182
'}]
commit_message:
Handle ansible_runner return code properly

returning and raising exceptions are mutually exclusive. we need to
return rc properly from run_ansible_playbook() for it to be used
later in tripleo deploy.

Change-Id: Ia07433fb6886931530afebad49c8b6bf1f062af5
Closes-Bug: #1859182

[{'created': '2020-01-13 16:20:20.000000000', 'message': 'horizon: put plugins toggles in quotes

Without quotes, it seems like Ansible "from_yaml" filter will convert
yes to True and no to False; which is problematic in the case of Kolla
image for Horizon where the extend_start script checks for yes/no and
not the actual booleans.

Putting them between quotes seems to solve the issue.

Change-Id: Ie08726c0916c55c3d4c315b63ee341196cc2e70e
Closes-Bug: #1859491
'}]
commit_message:
horizon: put plugins toggles in quotes

Without quotes, it seems like Ansible "from_yaml" filter will convert
yes to True and no to False; which is problematic in the case of Kolla
image for Horizon where the extend_start script checks for yes/no and
not the actual booleans.

Putting them between quotes seems to solve the issue.

Change-Id: Ie08726c0916c55c3d4c315b63ee341196cc2e70e
Closes-Bug: #1859491

commit_message:
Fixes rally db commands

'rally-manage db' command was deprecated since 0.10.0 [1]. Should use
'rally db' instead.

[1] https://rally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/project_info/release_notes/archive/v0.10.0.html#command-line-interface

Closes-Bug: #1856693

Change-Id: I578f7a6d907d5579180bc64c99c7e6c8edf3afc8
(cherry picked from commit 1114859b5cb940290f405cd64e34c6638dcebcae)

commit_message:
Remove reference to deprecated [disk_utils]iscsi_verify_attempts

The configuration option [disk_utils]iscsi_verify_attempts was
deprecated in Train and it's been removed from ironic-lib.

[{'created': '2020-01-13 21:58:06.000000000', 'message': 'Generate PEP503 index pages for wheel mirrors

PEP503 [1] defines the simple respository API format that we should
follow for our mirrors publishing .whl files.

This loops the output directories and creates a index.html for each
project with the required tags.

We do not really have gate testing for this, so to avoid destroying
the whole mirror we write out a temporary index file first to check.
When this works, we will revert to index.html and do a single manual
removal of the temporary indexes.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/

Change-Id: I0541fb58535f27589b7e3bc1462cb083e3d12f56

This loops the output directories and creates a index.html for each
project with the required tags.

We do not really have gate testing for this, so to avoid destroying

manual removal of the temporary indexes.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/

Change-Id: I0541fb58535f27589b7e3bc1462cb083e3d12f56
'}]
commit_message:
Generate PEP503 index pages for wheel mirrors

PEP503 [1] defines the simple respository API format that we should
follow for our mirrors publishing .whl files.

This loops the output directories and creates a index.html for each
project with the required tags.

We do not really have gate testing for this, so to avoid destroying
the whole mirror we write out a temporary index file first, and ignore
errors.  When this works, we will revert to index.html and do a single
manual removal of the temporary indexes.

[1] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/

Change-Id: I0541fb58535f27589b7e3bc1462cb083e3d12f56

commit_message:
Update hacking, fix errors/warnings

This version of hacking doesn't understand f-strings as usable in
Python 3.  Update to the latest and fix current issues, which are all
just formatting fixes.

Change-Id: I0a7d6f93f07477b6dd29ab143130dd9064c250be

commit_message:
Correct availability_zone to be non-mandatory in heat

As per CLI and GUI, availability_zone is not mandatory.  In templates,
it is.  This is incorrect.

This patch corrects behaviour to match CLI and GUI.

Change-Id: Ice37340f084ea65bd4b46562145e82ede6bc0df5
Story: 2006586
(cherry picked from commit 2799a5fcd76639a202092ea1b6fc242a8886dc56)

messages:
[{'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2020-01-02 07:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2020-01-02 08:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

The current gate is running with all versions above rocky, so we need to backport this to rocky and make gate stable (see comment in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700854)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-06 19:05:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-02 07:58:01.000000000', 'message': 'Eliminate race in CancelUpdateTest

The purpose of this test is to ensure we can rollback an in-progress
Server resource with attached ports. However, by cancelling immediately
we create a race whereby the stack may be rolled back before we have
even started updating the stack, in which case we are not testing the
behaviour we actually care about. Inserting a delay gives Heat enough
time to process the Port and start updating the Server before we cancel
the update.

In some circumstances this could also trigger a race within Heat,
whereby the rollback traversal would not block, but the update traversal
would retrigger it anyway. This resulted in the stack rollback being
marked COMPLETE multiple times, which could also lead to errors in
deleting the old raw_template after it had already been removed. The
latter have been fixed by separate patches. The race itself should be
addressed separately.

Change-Id: I3f9db686c31659437ff4797555e6608986946572
Task: 37199
(cherry picked from commit 3b4e0cda282e3df64daf16d64081faa47dd72135)
'}]
commit_message:
Eliminate race in CancelUpdateTest

The purpose of this test is to ensure we can rollback an in-progress
Server resource with attached ports. However, by cancelling immediately
we create a race whereby the stack may be rolled back before we have
even started updating the stack, in which case we are not testing the
behaviour we actually care about. Inserting a delay gives Heat enough
time to process the Port and start updating the Server before we cancel
the update.

In some circumstances this could also trigger a race within Heat,
whereby the rollback traversal would not block, but the update traversal
would retrigger it anyway. This resulted in the stack rollback being
marked COMPLETE multiple times, which could also lead to errors in
deleting the old raw_template after it had already been removed. The
latter have been fixed by separate patches. The race itself should be
addressed separately.

Change-Id: I3f9db686c31659437ff4797555e6608986946572
Task: 37199
(cherry picked from commit 3b4e0cda282e3df64daf16d64081faa47dd72135)

commit_message:
Update Elastic Beats versions to 7.1.0

This updates the Elastic Beats charts to 7.1.0 to keep them
aligned with the Kibana and Elasticsearch chart versions, which
is required for compatibility

This also updates the experimental job to use the single node
minikube deployment as opposed to the standard 5 node multinode
deployment

Change-Id: I4baba6ca2ea2f3785f11905138b67979a4501caa
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Fall back service_net_map to ctlplane

Render the service_net_map to fall back to the ctlplane network when
networks are disabled (or not defined) in network_data.yaml.

Also use startswith for Ceph roles which should all have 'storage'
as the HostnameResolveNetwork.

Conflicts:
	network/service_net_map.j2.yaml

Closes-Bug: #1809313
Change-Id: I737d5656b113f7e2238fe7bb555cc2d4cb13877c
(cherry picked from commit 3df5f8db1ecb2e276d8744ad796a029a0f0a5a6e)

commit_message:
[Gate] Update gate

The OSH-addons jobs have been outdated for quite some time in comparison to
OSH and OSH-Infra jobs. This patch set updates the jobs to be inline with
the jobs in the other repositories.

Change-Id: I5a75806ab88d18caecff19ae09d094d82e6eafb2
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

commit_message:
Apparmor: Update to use the runtime default profile

This moves from using the docker profile to the default
runtime profile - which allows container engines other than
docker to work out of the box.

Change-Id: Ica5a48f8c43b90f07969b41e10dc472a772b5b43
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

subject: Fix OS::Neutron::ExtraRoute delete with IPv6
messages:
[{'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 11:47:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 11:47:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

unit test might be good'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 12:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 12:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

all the devstack tests are failing due to current setuptools woes'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-13 15:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 18:29:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 18:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2020-01-13 18:32:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2020-01-13 20:38:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-13 11:47:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix OS::Neutron::ExtraRoute delete with IPv6

currently Heat sets the resource_id of the ExtraRoute resource to
`<router_id>:<destination>:<nexthop>`
and later parses destination and nexthop out from resource_id on delete
of the resource.
However colon is an integral part of IPv6 addresses, so such parsing
fails in this case.

In this patch we parse only the router_id from the resource_id
(expecting that there can not be any colons in UUID of the router),
and use actual resource properties to find destination and nexthop,
avoiding the parsing error.

Change-Id: I6835efc632c38aac3466d3952f8887ef15dbd0ad
Story: 2007085
Task: 38080
'}, {'created': '2020-01-13 12:52:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix OS::Neutron::ExtraRoute delete with IPv6

currently Heat sets the resource_id of the ExtraRoute resource to
`<router_id>:<destination>:<nexthop>`
and later parses destination and nexthop out from resource_id on delete
of the resource.
However colon is an integral part of IPv6 addresses, so such parsing
fails in this case.

In this patch we parse only the router_id from the resource_id
(expecting that there can not be any colons in UUID of the router),
and use actual resource properties to find destination and nexthop,
avoiding the parsing error.

commit_message:
Fix OS::Neutron::ExtraRoute delete with IPv6

currently Heat sets the resource_id of the ExtraRoute resource to
`<router_id>:<destination>:<nexthop>`
and later parses destination and nexthop out from resource_id on delete
of the resource.
However colon is an integral part of IPv6 addresses, so such parsing
fails in this case.

In this patch we use actual resource properties to find
router_id, destination and nexthop, thus avoiding the parsing error.

Change-Id: I6835efc632c38aac3466d3952f8887ef15dbd0ad
Story: 2007085
Task: 38080

commit_message:
Use new ODL diagstatus heath check REST endpoint

OpenDaylight's Infrautils project has a new, recommended method for
checking when ODL is up and ready. Use this new diagstatus ODL NB REST
API endpoint vs the old netvirt:1 endpoint.

This should make any operations that check if ODL is ready more
reliable. Deployments, for example.

Applies to all currently-supported ODL releases.

ODL Jira that tracked adding diagstatus REST API:

https://jira.opendaylight.org/browse/INFRAUTILS-33

RH BZ tracking moving puppet-neutron to diagstatus:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1642270

Also add corresponding release notes.

Change-Id: I04aefea91f435db7896e1e065c81a05796d6c4e5
Signed-off-by: Daniel Farrell <dfarrell@redhat.com>

Until now-ish Volume v3 has been a pass-through to v2.  In order
to prepare to make the Volume v3 commands stand-alone copy the
v2 functional tests to v3.

This is the first of a series of reviews to completely separate
Volume v2 and v3 commands.  Once these are split we can begin to
implement v3 microversion support and/or start using the
OpenStack SDK as the REST library.

Change-Id: Iefd78d8ef6bb851d7360596337a88ee8f8476767
Signed-off-by: Dean Troyer <dtroyer@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Create Volume v3 functional tests

Until now-ish Volume v3 has been a pass-through to v2.  In order
to prepare to make the Volume v3 commands stand-alone copy the
v2 functional tests to v3.

This is the first of a series of reviews to completely separate
Volume v2 and v3 commands.  Once these are split we can begin to
implement v3 microversion support and/or start using the
OpenStack SDK as the REST library.

Change-Id: Iefd78d8ef6bb851d7360596337a88ee8f8476767
Signed-off-by: Dean Troyer <dtroyer@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add enhance_help kwarg to tags option generators

Some callers, such as python-openstackclient needing to deal with
consolidated neutron and nova-network documentation builds, need to be
able to decorate help texts in certain circumstances. This commit adds
an enhance_help kwarg to the tag-related option generators. The kwarg
accepts a callable, which by default is a no-op.

Change-Id: If700daf8a38b1c426bcfcb5ac37202e8aa0178e5

commit_message:
Fix update API when barbican secret is missing

API update calls were blocked if the load balancer had a TLS
terminated listener that the secret has been removed from barbican.
This patch corrects this problem allowing users to update the
certificate reference.

Change-Id: I96908e6cbdb523f95298aff463a749d15e98e1ad
Story: 2006676
Task: 37322
(cherry picked from commit 5af97a248b2c20cd12d743b124fec9848b1d965c)

commit_message:
Enable metrics qdr to use public VIP

This patch adds HAProxy configuration for MetricsQdr service, so that
QDRs running on controller nodes in interior mode can be accessed
by external clients (such as CloudForms)

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/700250
Change-Id: I048cebe08d5e63693799b93c649231acfc772922

commit_message:
Use distro_python_version in fernet-node-sync

Since Debian and Ubuntu are already on Python3 only and don't have unversioned
Python binaries (no /usr/bin/python) - we need to call the fetch-fernet-tokens
script using distro_python_version

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
guestfs: Log a useful error when the required vmlinuz isn't found

This change adds a simple breadcrumb when Libguestfs fails to start in
containerised environments where the installed kernel can differ from
the running kernel.

Change-Id: Ied67c690d281b99f50106e7983d41dca90099954

commit_message:
Lower RAM for DIB jobs to 2 GiB

The CentOS 8 images we use now are much smaller than the previously
used CentOS 7 images, so hopefully we can require less RAM.

Change-Id: I876cd4af8fe9a0516c0802f3894a964000d0ae2b

commit_message:
Add calico_ipv4pool_ipip label

IPIP Mode to use for the IPv4 POOL created at start up
allowed_values: ["Always", "CrossSubnet", "Never", "Off"]
default: "Off"

Change-Id: Ib834a1f86a6db408047cc8f86fc7744d16d83904
Signed-off-by: Diogo Guerra <diogo.filipe.tomas.guerra@cern.ch>

subject: Update provider config spec for identification conflicts
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 29334, 'name': 'Dakshina Ilangovan', 'email': 'dakshina.ilangovan@intel.com', 'username': 'dakshinai'}, {'_account_id': 29745, 'name': 'Dustin Cowles', 'email': 'cowlesd@gmail.com', 'username': 'dustinc', 'status': 'inactive'}, {'_account_id': 30001, 'name': 'Ivens Zambrano', 'email': 'ivens.zambrano@intel.com', 'username': 'IvensZambrano'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-11-07 19:33:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-08 15:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Hm. This might be the right thing. But I want to put this alternative out there for consideration (and noodle it myself for a bit):

It might be more "intuitive" if $COMPUTE_NODE was always treated as the default, and any explicit name/uuid takes precedence no matter where it falls in the sort order.

Then we still have to deal with conflicts of name+uuid, which could be done as first-seen like you're suggesting here.

...which is more complex to document, so I'm really not sure if it's better. I need to noodle it out, and would like to hear feedback from others.

By the way, this gets a lot easier if we rip out the `name` identification method entirely. Then we can let UUIDs take precedence over $COMPUTE_NODE, and just 100% bounce early if we find a duplicate UUID. So -- remind me why we insisted we needed to support `name`? I want to say it was gibi who was pushing for that. (I'll go paw through the original spec review later if nobody remembers off the top.)'}, {'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-11-09 01:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> It might be more "intuitive" if $COMPUTE_NODE was always treated as the default

I agree, though processing in order allows the operator more flexibility. I am not sure of an exact use case where they would want a processed-first-$COMPUTE_NODE file to take precedence, but there may be one...'}, {'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-11-15 18:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-11-21 00:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-21 00:11:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

This is good. We also talked about making it so runtime-detected conflicts would cause that provider to be ignored, with an error logged. But I'm fine if that's left as an implementation detail."}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-11-21 00:21:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29745, 'date': '2019-11-21 18:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29334, 'date': '2019-11-22 00:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-22 00:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-01-13 20:39:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-07 19:33:10.000000000', 'message': 'Spec: Provider config YAML file

During implementation it was found that there is no reliable method
to identify identification conflicts between actual UUID/NAME and
UUID:$COMPUTE_NODE before the point at which we cannot allow the loading
process to fail. Since the spec previously required failure on an
identification conflict, I am proposing this change to ignore additional
entries when an identification conflict is detected.

Change-Id: If64509785675442ed9e8e8e452bf7dac837c1953
Blueprint: provider-config-file
'}, {'created': '2019-11-15 18:18:47.000000000', 'message': 'Update provider config spec for identification conflicts

During implementation it was found that there is no reliable method
to identify identification conflicts between actual UUID/NAME and
UUID:$COMPUTE_NODE before the point at which we cannot allow the loading
process to fail. Since the spec previously required failure on an
identification conflict, I am proposing this change to ignore additional
entries when an identification conflict is detected.

Change-Id: If64509785675442ed9e8e8e452bf7dac837c1953
Blueprint: provider-config-file
'}, {'created': '2019-11-21 00:06:38.000000000', 'message': 'Update provider config spec for identification conflicts

During implementation it was found that there is no reliable method
to identify identification conflicts between actual UUID/NAME and
UUID:$COMPUTE_NODE before the point at which we cannot allow the loading
process to fail. Since the spec previously required failure on an
identification conflict, I am proposing this change to allow for the
use of both by ignoring $COMPUTE_NODE entries if a UUID/NAME record
also exists.

Change-Id: If64509785675442ed9e8e8e452bf7dac837c1953
Blueprint: provider-config-file
'}]
commit_message:
Update provider config spec for identification conflicts

During implementation it was found that there is no reliable method
to identify identification conflicts between actual UUID/NAME and
UUID:$COMPUTE_NODE before the point at which we cannot allow the loading
process to fail. Since the spec previously required failure on an
identification conflict, I am proposing this change to allow for the
use of both by ignoring $COMPUTE_NODE entries if a UUID/NAME record
also exists.

Change-Id: If64509785675442ed9e8e8e452bf7dac837c1953
Blueprint: provider-config-file

commit_message:
Adds bandit nosec flag to hashlib.sha1

A bandit patch to block sha1 hash is failing CI [1], due to a false
positive on hashlib.sha1 (which actually uses HMAC-SHA1 in keystone
that is considered more secure then standard SHA1)

This change marks a # nosec comment against the line which is
triggering the false positive in Bandit.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/437563/6

Change-Id: Ib9618119c77f41fba0e612e37c7511676bed47e8

commit_message:
Switch to reader context

Since the mtu is already non-nullable, the writer context
can be switched to a reader context. In addition, the redundant
reader context can be removed.

Change-Id: I482a3892dee8ee94ab70142cf734f71e766178ed
Closes-Bug: #1859258

commit_message:
Fix failure due to setuptools dropping support for py2

Done by preventing virtualenv from installing setuptools and
then installing them via pip in the virtualenv with pin <45.

Change-Id: If56c1b6a25c8bf1890f77b8b1adfae7b10b78063
Story: 2007083
Task: 38064

[{'created': '2019-12-17 15:32:19.000000000', 'message': "Change the python interpreter discovery mode.

Current default mode for the python interpreter discover inansible 2.8 is
auto_legacy. This patch changes the mode to auto, the biggest difference
respecting auto_legacy is 'If no entry is found, or the listed Python is
not present on the target host, searches a list of common Python interpreter
paths and uses the first one found' [0].
Currently, it has been observed some issues with the
discovered_python_interpreter fact not getting updated on specific scenarios
(for example, when upgrading the node from RHEL7 to RHEL8). This change is
expected to improve this situation.

[0] - https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/interpreter_discovery.html#
Related-Bug: #1856313
Change-Id: Iaef4839bb15ec398537b5c57a441c8e28a552bc0

commit_message:
Change the python interpreter discovery mode.

Current default mode for the python interpreter discover inansible 2.8 is
auto_legacy. This patch changes the mode to auto, the biggest difference
respecting auto_legacy is 'If no entry is found, or the listed Python is
not present on the target host, searches a list of common Python interpreter
paths and uses the first one found' [0].
Currently, it has been observed some issues with the
discovered_python_interpreter fact not getting updated on specific scenarios
(for example, when upgrading the node from RHEL7 to RHEL8). This change is
expected to improve this situation.

[0] - https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/interpreter_discovery.html#
Related-Bug: #1856313
Change-Id: Iaef4839bb15ec398537b5c57a441c8e28a552bc0
(cherry picked from commit 6b4f47dd4245133294e459d9a7d0c38fc9af21a6)
(cherry picked from commit 62d24f121efc40835581e0e0a48e82e0a6f392fb)

commit_message:
Remove redundant OpenStackShell.prepare_to_run_command

osc-lib's OpenStackShell.prepare_to_run_command has been a superset of
python-openstackclient's since at least osc-lib 1.4.0. We require 1.14.0
now, so the redundant override can be removed.

commit_message:
Add dns_publish_fixed_ip attribute to subnets

With the subnet_dns_publish_fixed_ip extension Neutron has added a new
attribute to subnets, allowing to select whether DNS records should be
published for fixed IPs from that subnet. Add support for this when
creating and updating subnets.

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1784879
[1] https://review.opendev.org/662405
[2] https://review.opendev.org/662409

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/679833
Change-Id: Ia804e878acfd1f05e1f00c2ac9202c1d260827f4

This includes dropping py2, so since that is a backwards incompatible change, this needs to be a 2.0.0 release.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-01-12 11:44:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
 > 
 > This includes dropping py2, so since that is a backwards incompatible change, this needs to be a 2.0.0 release.

This new minor release does not drop py2 support, but only adds a patch for an existing problem in 1.31.0. Why do you say this version is doing this?

Please, make a diff between 1.31.0 and 1.31.1 versions.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-01-12 11:46:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Ufffff you are right!!

Sean, thanks for your review!'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-12 13:50:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

neutron-lib 1.31.0 is part of ussuri cycle, so we don't necessarily have a new release with a bug fix only. We merged python2 drop (major version bump), so we need to bump a major version. I think 2.0.0 would be fine for the new release.

Another question is whether we need to block neutron-lib 1.31.0 or not.  I don't think we need to block neutron-lib 1.31.0. IMHO there is no actual consumer at the moment as a new feature in neutron is expected to use it.

Thanks,
Akihiro"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-01-12 17:47:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 > 
 > Another question is whether we need to block neutron-lib 1.31.0 or
 > not.  I don't think we need to block neutron-lib 1.31.0. IMHO there
 > is no actual consumer at the moment as a new feature in neutron is
 > expected to use it.
 > 
 > Thanks,
 > Akihiro

1.31.0 introduces a bug in the port API definition, preventing from updating the QoS policy in the port. This version should be blocked."}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-01-12 17:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-01-12 20:42:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

IMO version 2.0.0 is also fine for that as it's python 3 only now."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-13 08:08:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Rodolfo Alonso Hernandez wrote:

 > Another question is whether we need to block neutron-lib 1.31.0 or

 > expected to use it.
 > 
 > Thanks,
 > Akihiro
>
> 1.31.0 introduces a bug in the port API definition, preventing from

Thanks for clarification. I misunderstood the situation a bit.

commit_message:
Release neutron-lib 2.0.0 for Ussuri

Features:
- Drops Python 2 support.

Fixes:
- Introduces a fix for a port API extension: the extension was
  redefining the "qos_policy_id" parameter, instead of adding
  the new one "qos_network_policy_id".

Change-Id: Ic2d6a6c13570a006633bb2150ceb741e3e20f24a

commit_message:
Raise flake8-import-order version to latest

We had this library capped at a release that is a few years old. Now
that we have dropped py2 testing, we can pick up the latest version.

This uncovered a few things to clean up. Mostly the fact that mock is
now a part of the StdLib unittest since Python 3.3.

Change-Id: I27484dd4c25378413ff16e97a35a1a46062357bc
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Improve document 'openstack complete'

The openstack complete command requires bash-completion package
Without the relevant package the bash completion doesn't work.

Change-Id: I47c77f3e7efe112417d2b96936fcd0cafeb9442e
Closes-Bug: #1798493
(cherry picked from commit 4173690b2492680ab504ef0d60498eeb5a3d8ae2)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6816, 'name': 'Jesse Pretorius', 'email': 'jesse@odyssey4.me', 'username': 'jesse-pretorius'}, {'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 9061, 'name': 'David Moreau Simard', 'email': 'moi@dmsimard.com', 'username': 'dmsimard'}, {'_account_id': 9555, 'name': 'Matthew Booth', 'email': 'mbooth@redhat.com', 'username': 'MatthewBooth'}, {'_account_id': 9592, 'name': 'wes hayutin', 'email': 'whayutin@redhat.com', 'username': 'weshayutin'}, {'_account_id': 10969, 'name': 'Shnaidman Sagi (Sergey)', 'display_name': 'Shnaidman Sagi', 'email': 'sshnaidm@redhat.com', 'username': 'sergsh'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24245, 'name': 'Harald Jenss', 'email': 'hjensas@redhat.com', 'username': 'harald.jensas'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:13:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:54:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

LGTM and is a lot simpler to grok and maintain, I think. If any downstream resources are relying on the included ipxe/*.qcow2 files that may be an issue which needs resolving.'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:33:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> LGTM and is a lot simpler to grok and maintain, I think. If any
 > downstream resources are relying on the included ipxe/*.qcow2 files
 > that may be an issue which needs resolving.

The TripleO jobs running off of the RDO Zuul are using this image and there is currently no automation in place to update it if it changes.

The image is currently just uploaded once to the clouds where the jobs are running.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:37:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

please hold for third party :)
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1845225'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:37:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > LGTM and is a lot simpler to grok and maintain, I think. If any
 > > downstream resources are relying on the included ipxe/*.qcow2
 > files
 > > that may be an issue which needs resolving.
 > 
 > The TripleO jobs running off of the RDO Zuul are using this image
 > and there is currently no automation in place to update it if it
 > changes.
 > 
 > The image is currently just uploaded once to the clouds where the
 > jobs are running.

I'm happy to put the image back in, but I'd prefer to fix whatever requires it to exist. If you can point me at the relevant job description I'll try to work out a sequence to fix both.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:49:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This breaks the documented deploy flow, which relies on the in-repo image. I'm not really a fan of removing the ipxe image from the repo, especially if it's getting even smaller. 62 seconds is still longer than 0 and it does add another potential point of failure for no particular benefit that I can see. Also, git submodules are pretty widely disliked for good reasons.

As David mentioned, this won't be tested by ci anyway and will need manual verification. Cloud admins will have to update the image for it to take effect after it merges."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-25 08:36:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Sounds like it will be easier to put the pre-built image back.

I'll also put the -41 image back if you really want, but as below I think it should be accompanied by an explanation of why it's there. I think I'm inferring that it's there because some automated job somewhere expects it to be there? Honestly that code should just resize it for its own use case, whatever that is.

As for submodules, I'm ambivalent. I have heard folks don't like them, but I've never understood why. The alternative would be to have the Makefile check out the git repo, I guess. However, I suspect that using git native submodules is going to be better than whatever we'd hack up ourselves. I'm not going to change that unless there's a strong objection, so please be clear if you really don't want to use a submodule!"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-25 08:46:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As for manual testing, is there some rpm I can rebuild to contain my image to make testing easier?'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-09-25 09:02:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Looks like the images need to be added back.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-25 10:49:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-09-25 11:03:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-09-25 15:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-09-25 16:35:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> As for manual testing, is there some rpm I can rebuild to contain
 > my image to make testing easier?

Unfortunately not. It just needs to get added to the host cloud where someone is running OVB. CI could probably be modified to build and upload the image on a per-job basis, but previously it wasn't necessary because the image didn't change much."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2019-09-26 08:31:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I think this looks good. But, we probably want to wait for https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1845225.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-26 11:16:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-09-26 11:23:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I've decided to leave this patch alone and add a follow-up patch which removes the pre-build image and doxxes bnemec as discussed ;)

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685037/1"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-10-07 10:41:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-10-14 13:04:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-10-24 17:15:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

> I've decided to leave this patch alone and add a follow-up patch
 > which removes the pre-build image and doxxes bnemec as discussed ;)
 > 
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/685037/1

The only downside of doing this that I see is it makes these temporary images a permanent part of the git history. Then again, they're significantly smaller than the previous images so that's probably not a huge deal.

I'm holding off on approving anything until I hear from someone that CI is in a good place to start making these changes again. Although it's worth noting that I doubt these changes will affect CI until someone manually uploads the new image to the host cloud(s)."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-13 22:04:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-23 14:13:19.000000000', 'message': "Don't use diskimage-builder to build IPXE image

IPXE's build process already creates bootable images, so we just use one of
those. This builds much faster, has far fewer dependencies, and produces
a much smaller image. The largest difference in output is that the
resulting image no longer uses grub, but as we weren't using any
features of grub this also means a faster boot time.

For reference, a full build takes 62 seconds on my laptop. The new
Makefile also handles dependencies much better so, for example, an
incremental rebuild after changing the embedded script takes under 3
seconds.

We no longer store the resulting build artifacts in the git repo, as
images are now buildable quickly with minimal dependencies.

The ipxe repo changes to being a submodule, which continues to allow us
to pin it to a specific commit.

We no longer build the -41 image, as that was oddly specific to some
undescribed use-case. It's also trivial for whoever needed it to do
themselves if the use case is still relevant.

Change-Id: I5a6a990e6966d6eeaa2aa87cd89bfbac6738f6ee

commit_message:
Don't use diskimage-builder to build IPXE image

IPXE's build process already creates bootable images, so we just use one of
those. This builds much faster, has far fewer dependencies, and produces
a much smaller image. The largest difference in output is that the
resulting image no longer uses grub, but as we weren't using any
features of grub this also means a faster boot time.

For reference, a full build takes 62 seconds on my laptop. The new
Makefile also handles dependencies much better so, for example, an
incremental rebuild after changing the embedded script takes under 3
seconds.

The ipxe repo changes to being a submodule, which continues to allow us
to pin it to a specific commit.

We no longer build the -41 image, as that was oddly specific to some
undescribed use-case. It's also trivial for whoever needed it to do
themselves if the use case is still relevant.

Change-Id: I5a6a990e6966d6eeaa2aa87cd89bfbac6738f6ee

commit_message:
[ceph-rgw] Delete bucket and objects from failed deploy

Validate that the container bucket exist and if so
delete it and its objects that were orphaned from a
a failed deployment helm-tests.

Change-Id: Ibaa6d0f6dd36b319c354b65e43dc6053418f4d1d

commit_message:
Update hacking version to 1.1.x

This commit updates hacking version in test-requirements
and fixes some related pep8 issues

Also ignores false positive bandit test
B105: hardcoded_password_string,
B106: hardcoded_password_funcarg
based on variable or argument names.
For more info refer [1][2]

[1] https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b105_hardcoded_password_string.html
[2] https://bandit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/b106_hardcoded_password_funcarg.html

Change-Id: If779ebad11926594961577e0744093a8ba691610
Story: 2004930
Task: 29314
(cherry picked from commit 3404a6df722b8f85c425d15769a0e831891cdc2c)

commit_message:
Add support for gathering Slab memory usage

This is useful, for example when monitoring Slab memory leaks. To support
gathering this metric a minimum version of psutil 5.4.4 is required
(released on Apr 13th 2018).

Story: 2006815
Task: 37375
Change-Id: Ibe8def9e2a7c967a34236889aa03b287065abcdc

commit_message:
Skip auth plugin creation with new OCC

In the next patch, in occ, we'll defer plugin loading to be on-demand in
the get_auth method. In order for that to fully work, we need to skip
our deferred plugin loading here if occ can defer plugin loading itself.

This patch should be a no-op before the occ patch.

Change-Id: I8d4dd9df0ea7364dec1a8de25d31e09d93dfa116

commit_message:
Add component release file for component promotion

Add a new component repo to the release file in order to run
on-the-fly updates to the container images for the component
testing.

https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1408

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/695690

Change-Id: Ic84c4c1584617bca520934edfc1204e788bfb2d1

commit_message:
The file option should not require environment variable.

The file option should not require log_url or LOG_PATH. Actually the
link variable can be an empty string.

Change-Id: I33439eb4748ef892fcf132d7cab766bc03dff038
Closes-Bug: #1742139

commit_message:
Enable external public endpoint for MetricsQdr

This patch adds public endpoint for MetricsQdr and makes the service to listen
on it when deployed on controller nodes (when enabled interior mode on controllers)

Change-Id: I0e4bb210064cc8a27dd3e041cb363c4add99662c

commit_message:
[Rocky] Removed passing tests from skiplist

Class neutron_tempest_plugin.scenario has maximum
number of tests passed. Hence, it is removed and
only failing testsis kept.

In addition to above, added two more tests from
class 'TestSecurityGroupsBasicOps' and a test from
class 'ServersOnMultiNodesTest'

Related-bug: #1737940
Related-bug: #1753209
Related-bug: #1843259
Related-bug: #1793482
Related-bug: #1831223
Related-bug: #1857365

Signed-off by: Soniya Vyas<svyas@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I8239bb694187d7f912163742e836a7362cdb1483

commit_message:
Drop use of unittest2

unittest2 was needed for Python versions <= 2.6, so it has not been
needed for quite some time. See unittest2 note on:

https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html

This drops unittest2 in favor of the standard unittest module.

Change-Id: I52c580a907272d4941228ddfcc7a52ade1e489c3
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Make tests pass in 2020

Without this patch, build failed after 2019-12-31 with
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/test_auth.py", line 226, in test_authenticate_success_password_unscoped
    self.assertRequestBodyIs(json=self.TEST_REQUEST_BODY)
  File "keystoneclient/tests/unit/utils.py", line 72, in assertRequestBodyIs
    self.assertEqual(json, val)

NOTE: in addition to the orginal backport, this patch adds the following
changes. The changes has to be combined into a single patch in order to
avoid circular dependencies.

1. fixed bandit complains in keystoneclient/common/cms.py. The literal 'sha256'
is the default hash algorithm, not a sensitive password. Marking it as false
positive so bandit can stop chirping.

2. combined with cherry pick from commit
f2d3fec9b254f9c47e97ddf48e3c5f7614b87f1b to avoid circular dependency. Without
combining them, neither backport will pass all the gates since pep8 has
switched over to use python3 now.

Change-Id: I0e44d9896c5970f0ca07438c372aec826aeb5c77
(cherry picked from commit f2d3fec9b254f9c47e97ddf48e3c5f7614b87f1b)
(cherry picked from commit acc21ff06154e16de16583fe6994207d689ed054)

commit_message:
Use Python 3 by default and drop Python 2

Follow the rest of OpenStack and consistently switch to
python3 as default python interpreter and drop python2.

The "functional" tox target was failing with Python 2
as cinder/master has cut the Python 2.7 compatibility.
"functional" now points to the default python3. An explicit
"functional-py37" target has been added as well.

Fix the functional jobs as well:
- move the LVM job to centos-8 and adapt it when needed;
- move the Ceph job to ubuntu-bionic, as there are no
  CentOS 8 Ceph packages (and the CentOS 7 ones do not
  provide Python 3 bindings).

Closes-Bug: #1853372
Change-Id: Iea4f4f53df7400248848399494564910d3870f63

commit_message:
Allow overrides in non global ceph.conf sections

In current ceph-base version there is a CephConfigOverride
parameter which allows to override ceph.conf params in global
section only.

This change will permit overrides to specify the ceph.conf
section into which they apply, while retaining backward
compatiblity.

Also adds in scenarios 001 and 004 some test cases.

Co-Authored-By: Giulio Fidente <gfidente@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Icaba7a58f458d853912d038f24c0cb4f853e0166
Implements: blueprint ceph-config-overrides
(cherry picked from commit 2501f4747c609482ac4e500aaf8ed5519e174bc7)

commit_message:
Set 'unknown' address properly when port sec is disabled

Previous to this patch, the 'unknown' address was added to the
OVN Logical_Switch_Port row. However, the '<ip> <mac1> <macN>'
was still there so the port security was not really disabled.

The correct behavior is to set the 'addresses' field to 'unknown'
and remove everything else.

Change-Id: Icb5ad0fd2f3cdff668f51a5847bf6cef9f48478b
Closes-Bug: #1728886
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

subject: Fix Zun Docker runtime selection
messages: [{'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-10 20:15:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2020-01-11 02:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2020-01-13 08:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2020-01-13 12:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-01-13 14:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/train as commit c6ff77a9c1187c08f88318b94d78ce1b9a1782f6'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-10 20:15:14.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Zun Docker runtime selection

Per [1] Docker uses API version 1.26 since daemon version 1.13.1.
Kolla Ansible forced a limit on the Docker API version reported
to Zun of 1.24 which was surprising users and preventing
usage of Docker runtime selection via Zun.
The default of Zun is 1.26 [2] which enables runtime selection.
Zun does not use this parameter for anything else atm.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.26/#section/Versioning
[2] https://review.opendev.org/490794

Change-Id: Ide6eb4c2b079cf35e633ad6a04db1587e40e7633
Closes-bug: #1859176
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Zun Docker runtime selection

Per [1] Docker uses API version 1.26 since daemon version 1.13.1.
Kolla Ansible forced a limit on the Docker API version reported
to Zun of 1.24 which was surprising users and preventing
usage of Docker runtime selection via Zun.
The default of Zun is 1.26 [2] which enables runtime selection.
Zun does not use this parameter for anything else atm.

[1] https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.26/#section/Versioning
[2] https://review.opendev.org/490794

Change-Id: Ide6eb4c2b079cf35e633ad6a04db1587e40e7633
Closes-bug: #1859176

commit_message:
DNM Explicitly tear down software RAID after testing it

Having software RAID left on a node can interfere with other tests.
Tear it down in the end of the test.

Change-Id: I769bd677669fab3b8f032c8f113a6da28934ba89

commit_message:
Remove extra backslash in awk for tripleo-ceph-uuid role

This backslash caused bug 1854209. Whitespace in the
multi embedded in YAML is complicated. Seems safer to
just remove it in this case.

Change-Id: I8414a776360700b05fb18d73862797b13a58f32d
Closes-Bug: #1854209
(cherry picked from commit 7d935a5be428d7b05be740bd326c3a78e3af3fab)

commit_message:
Use python -m pip instead pip command.

It's recommand to use this way. With tox is not really necessary to do
it but it can be good to use it. See this article:

https://snarky.ca/why-you-should-use-python-m-pip/

For example python -m pip executes pip using the Python interpreter
you specified as python.

Change-Id: Ia17e693cc93a3b2f0ef460a3768d120feb9280ad

commit_message:
[Train] Remove passing tests from skiplist

Tests which are passing are being removed from the skiplist
with this patch.

Along with that, class
neutron_tempest_plugin.api.test_networks has maximum no. of
tests passing, so just kept failing test and other all tests
are removed.

Related-Bug: #1753209
Related-Bug: #1793482

Co-Authored-by: Soniya Vyas<svyas@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-by: Suraj Patil<surpatil@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I6a18555ba74018495daee5e5e6479bd2bd0427fd

commit_message:
Use distro_python_version in fernet-node-sync

Since Debian and Ubuntu are already on Python3 only and don't have unversioned
Python binaries (no /usr/bin/python) - we need to call the fetch-fernet-tokens
script using distro_python_version

Backport: train
Related-Bug: #1859047
Change-Id: I42378af9b25f14079fc57b4068ab25d5d4877362

commit_message:
Fixes rally db commands

'rally-manage db' command was deprecated since 0.10.0 [1]. Should use
'rally db' instead.

[1] https://rally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/project_info/release_notes/archive/v0.10.0.html#command-line-interface

Closes-Bug: #1856693

Change-Id: I578f7a6d907d5579180bc64c99c7e6c8edf3afc8

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-12 08:32:46.000000000', 'message': 'Drop use of unittest2

unittest2 was needed for compatibility with python <= 2.6, so we have
not needed this for quite some time now. See unittest2 note on:

https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html

This drops the use of unittest2 in favor of the standard unittest
package.

Change-Id: I46ec317f0ee43ff95d8af1aa68b8d0596dc4dd35
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Drop use of unittest2

unittest2 was needed for compatibility with python <= 2.6, so we have
not needed this for quite some time now. See unittest2 note on:

https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/unittest.html

This drops the use of unittest2 in favor of the standard unittest
package.

Change-Id: I46ec317f0ee43ff95d8af1aa68b8d0596dc4dd35
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
base: drop commented part about site-packages in Ubuntu

Turned out that since we commented mangling of system-wide Python
packages nothing broke. So let's get rid of that part.

subject: Allow mysql haproxy stanza do be customized
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-11 08:06:06.000000000', 'message': "Allow mysql haproxy stanza do be customized

We introduce a new tripleo::haproxy parameter called mysql_custom_listen_options
which can be used to customize mysql listen options in haproxy's config.

Tested as follows:
parameter_defaults:
  ExtraConfig:
    tripleo::haproxy::haproxy_default_timeout:
      - 'http-request 10s'
      - 'queue 2m'
      - 'connect 10s'
      - 'client 5m'
      - 'server 5m'
      - 'check 10s'
    tripleo::haproxy::cinder::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::glance_api::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::mysql_custom_listen_options:
      bind-process: 2

Observed that haproxy's mysql stanza had:
listen mysql
  bind 172.17.1.91:3306 transparent
  bind-process 2
  option tcpka
  option httpchk

Before this patch this was not the case and the tripleo::haproxy::<mysql>::options just got ignored.

Closes-Bug: #1858775

Change-Id: Ia0ecca5b54c1ca51898035e641665150dbdac9f7
(cherry picked from commit c42c5aa67828c8277d676e609bc828eb1dd1ba37)
(cherry picked from commit 64951b5c124b90e97404a7ad5c1439a768afbb2a)
(cherry picked from commit 48ff6171b51a70e6800fa87a7aec124ad6110cda)
"}]
commit_message:
Allow mysql haproxy stanza do be customized

We introduce a new tripleo::haproxy parameter called mysql_custom_listen_options
which can be used to customize mysql listen options in haproxy's config.

Tested as follows:
parameter_defaults:
  ExtraConfig:
    tripleo::haproxy::haproxy_default_timeout:
      - 'http-request 10s'
      - 'queue 2m'
      - 'connect 10s'
      - 'client 5m'
      - 'server 5m'
      - 'check 10s'
    tripleo::haproxy::cinder::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::glance_api::options:
      bind-process: 2
    tripleo::haproxy::mysql_custom_listen_options:
      bind-process: 2

Observed that haproxy's mysql stanza had:
listen mysql
  bind 172.17.1.91:3306 transparent
  bind-process 2
  option tcpka
  option httpchk

Before this patch this was not the case and the tripleo::haproxy::<mysql>::options just got ignored.

Closes-Bug: #1858775

Change-Id: Ia0ecca5b54c1ca51898035e641665150dbdac9f7
(cherry picked from commit c42c5aa67828c8277d676e609bc828eb1dd1ba37)
(cherry picked from commit 64951b5c124b90e97404a7ad5c1439a768afbb2a)
(cherry picked from commit 48ff6171b51a70e6800fa87a7aec124ad6110cda)

commit_message:
CI: use Debian/Ubuntu mirrors in base image

So far we built 'base' image using upstream mirrors and then replaced
them with OpenStack infra ones. Let do that right after we copy own
APT sources.list file.

Change-Id: Icb745f628c1c50d9f20df022b08ddc46fccc270c

commit_message:
Use hosts official name for FQDN

The current implementations use of a specific interface to build
FQDN from has the undesired side effect of the ``nova-compute`` and
``neutron-openvswitch`` charms ending up with using different
hostnames in some situations.  It may also lead to use of a
identifier that is mutable throughout the lifetime of a deployment.

Use of a specific interface was chosen due to ``socket.getfqdn()``
not giving reliable results (https://bugs.python.org/issue5004).

This patch gets the FQDN by mimicking the behaviour of a call to
``hostname -f`` with fallback to shortname on failure.

Add relevant update from c-h.

Depends-On: I82db81937e5a46dc6bd222b7160ca1fa5b190c10
Change-Id: Ic8f8742261b773484687985aa0a366391cd2737a
Closes-Bug: #1839300

commit_message:
Use hosts official name for FQDN

The current implementations use of a specific interface to build
FQDN from has the undesired side effect of the ``nova-compute`` and
``neutron-openvswitch`` charms ending up with using different
hostnames in some situations.  It may also lead to use of a
identifier that is mutable throughout the lifetime of a deployment.

Use of a specific interface was chosen due to ``socket.getfqdn()``
not giving reliable results (https://bugs.python.org/issue5004).

This patch gets the FQDN by mimickingthe behaviour of a call to
``hostname -f`` with fallback to shortname on failure.

Add relevant update from c-h.

Needed-By: Ic8f8742261b773484687985aa0a366391cd2737a
Change-Id: I82db81937e5a46dc6bd222b7160ca1fa5b190c10
Closes-Bug: #1839300

commit_message:
Fix stack.sh failing due to setuptools dropping support for py2

Done by preventing virtualenv from installing setuptools and
then installing them via pip in the virtualenv with pin <45.

Change-Id: Ic68e5cdb1a6f3554e79985c5a968e9417556fe4f

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-10 14:05:03.000000000', 'message': "Fix project name mapping to DLRN project name (v2)

This fixes failures produced when project name
doesn't starts with 'openstack/'

This is intended to unblock the use of tripleo-ci
that is now failing with projects that are not
hosted under the 'openstack/' prefix (like for
example x/tobiko).

Note: removed set -u because this can break source activate on old
versions of virtualenv.

As noted by marios, the role should not fail when it fails to find
a mapping, so it was refactored to assured that.

Change-Id: Ibb562f818419373700177f3b2e665cd4eb5e32ef
Partial-Bug: #1859167
Partial-Bug: #1858890

commit_message:
Fix project name mapping to DLRN project name (v2)

This fixes failures produced when project name
doesn't starts with 'openstack/'

This is intended to unblock the use of tripleo-ci
that is now failing with projects that are not
hosted under the 'openstack/' prefix (like for
example x/tobiko).

Note: removed set -u because this can break source activate on old
versions of virtualenv.

The role should not fail when it fails to find a mapping, so it was
refactored to assured that.

Also assures that the html report of Ansible is colored, making it
easier to read.

Change-Id: Ibb562f818419373700177f3b2e665cd4eb5e32ef
Partial-Bug: #1859167
Partial-Bug: #1858890
